review:
Have been using the 3.1GHz Intel Core i7 version of this new MacBook Pro with 16GB of memory and the 500GB flash storage, a significant upgrade from my previous early 2011 MacBook Pro. There have been quite a few changes, of course, in the four years between these units. Some of what I've noticed so far:

1) The keyboard has a slightly shorter throw for each key. As a result, there is a short period of getting used to the new keyboard, especially for the touch-typist. You'll find that you occasionally misstep, having a little difficulty double-hitting a character (such as for the word "hitting"). Spacing between keys has not changed. Ultimately the overall feel here is perfectly acceptable.

2) The sound quality has improved enormously. Listening to music is wonderful as both the amplitude and frequency response have improved. Stereo separation has also improved many-fold. Watching movies using the built-in audio is now enjoyable enough that I no longer feel like using headphones to improve the experience.

3) The retina screen makes more of a difference with text than I expected. I figured I'd see a difference only with photos - with those the change is quite significant - but even the text in the menubar is more legible than it was. Being able to increase the apparent resolution by scaling makes a big difference when I'm working with two documents at once. Your mileage may vary depending upon how farsighted you are, however, and at just over 50, I feel secure that I'd have liked this even more ten years ago!

4) Overall speed has improved dramatically for basics such as webpage loading, opening applications, restarts, and other common activities, particularly with feature-glutted applications like MS Office.

5) I missed the Ethernet port at first, but the Apple USB Ethernet Adapter works well on the MacBook. I definitely miss the CD-ROM drive as I used to use my MacBook to burn music CDs to use in the car. My government contractors still insist on providing documentation on disc, so for the time being I'm forced into schlepping an external CD drive with me much of the time. I fear it will be a few years at least until everyone is comfortable NOT using CDs to provide information.

6) The new trackpad was immediately intuitive. If you were comfortable with the older trackpads, this new interface will be comfortable from the start.

Out of the box, no problems, and migration from my old Mac took about an hour with a Thunderbolt-to-Thunderbolt cable.

UPDATE APRIL 2017

Over two years later, this Retina MBP is still going strong.  No problems of any kind.

I'm writing with a quick update to compare this to the new 13" Macbook Pro with Touch Bar released in November 2016.  I use one of these at work and feel I can offer a good comparison.

The new Touch Bar MBP's best feature in my opinion is the form factor:  it's 1/2 pound lighter, a bit slimmer, and has a smaller footprint than even the 13" Macbook Air.  Yet it packs a full-sized keyboard and gorgeous 13" display.

That's pretty much where the advantages end, in my opinion.  Despite a newer processor, it's no faster than my 2015 MBP.  The Touch Bar is a really cool idea but in day to day use it doesn't add much value to my experience.  Sometimes it makes you do more taps and presses to get to the thing you want, which is slightly annoying.  But I can totally live with the Touch Bar and have faith that it'll get better with newer software.

The keyboard in my opinion is awful.  It's the same keyboard they put on that new 12" super-skinny but underpowered Macbook.  My error rate is much higher on the Touch Bar MBP with its flat keyboard.

For some reason, the new Touch Bar MBP is less comfortable to hold.  The lines are somehow sharper.

I thought the switch to USB-C ports only would be super inconvenient.  It isn't, at least not for me.  Yes, I need dongles and adapters, but all of my USB devices work just fine with the new computer, and the dongles are really not that inconvenient.

My particular unit has an annoying defect:  there are some shorts in a few of the keyboard switches that randomly trigger certain Touch Bar actions.  That's a warranty issue and not likely to be a problem for you, but it further reduces my affection for the machine.

Bottom line, the 2015 MBP is still my favorite Macbook, and the one I'd buy again if mine were lost or stolen.  I

If you like the small form factor of the 2016 Touch Bar Macbook Pro, I'd suggest waiting until the fall or winter when the next iteration comes out with a faster processor and hopefully some of the other issues addressed.  Though it will still have a crappy keyboard.

Here's my original review of the early 2015 Macbook Pro:

--

I use my early 2015 13" Retina MBP pretty intensively every day.  I'm evaluating it relative to my 11" recent-year fully loaded MB Air and the most recent non-retina MB Pro, which I used for a year at work.

Here are my impressions of the 2015 rMBP so far, relative to these other Macbooks:

* Display

This is the main reason I bought the rMBP and I'm absolutely thrilled with it.  It blows away every other Macbook's display except of course the 15" retina MB Pro.  (The 15" Pro is too big and heavy for my needs, and is overdue for a refresh.)  For years, I've been running my MB Airs with an external monitor, a pretty decent 25" 1080p IPS display, and I was happy with this setup.  No more!  The external monitor and obviously the MB Air's display are a major step down from the rMBP's display.  I'm spoiled - it would be really hard for me to go back now that I'm used to the MBP's gorgeous high-res display.

* Weight

The 13" rMBP weighs 3.5 pounds.  Whether that feels like a burden or a breeze will depend on what you're comparing it to.

I'm coming from a 2.4 pound 11" Macbook Air, which I brought with me almost everywhere, including to work every day.  The extra pound of the 13" Pro is very noticeable.  The weight of the pro was the only reason I hesitated choosing it over a 2015 MB Air.

If you're comparing the Pro to the 13" MB Air, the Pro is only 1/2 pound heavier.  If you're comparing the Pro to similarly configured Windows laptops, many of which weigh 3 to 4 pounds, it's in the same ballpark in terms of size and weight.  If you're comparing the Pro to the 13" non-Retina Macbook Pro (yes they still sell these), the non-Retina Pro weighs a full pound more than the 13" rMBP.

For me, the Pro's extra weight relative to the MB Air is a compromise I'm willing to make in order to have a much more powerful machine with a much better display.  Plus, I no longer need to bring my laptop with me everywhere now; sometimes it's fine to just bring my iPad mini 2 and external keyboard.  (It helps that MS Office is available on iPad now, and IMHO it's pretty good.)

* Force track pad

The "force" part -- pressing the track pad harder to activate different features -- is not supported in most applications now, but more and more applications will support it in the coming year.  Until that happens, it works great as a regular trackpad - better than the (already excellent) trackpad on previous MB Pros and Airs.  I like using the new trackpad pretty well.  But it's not a killer feature, and in the future when more apps take advantage of it it will probably be like having a third mouse button--handy, but hardly essential.

* Speed & Performance

The 2015 rMBP has a newer generation of processor and graphics.  Everything feels very fast, including bootup times, app startup, running apps, ripping music CDs, etc.  That said, the 2014 model feels very fast, too, and I don't think most people will notice any speed improvements with the 2015 model over the 2014 model in normal everyday usage.

Apple claims the 2015 model's flash SSD is twice as fast as the SSD in the 2014 model.  Independent testing from professional review sites have verified this.  However, in normal usage, I don't notice much difference - the SSD in last year's model is pretty dang fast.

* Battery life

Apple claims 10 hours to a charge, compared with 9 hours on last year's model.  Independent tests by professional reviewers largely support Apple's claim:  Laptopmag.com reports 12 hours 4 minutes; PCMag.com gets 11 hours 10 minutes; CNET gets a whopping 15 hours 42 minutes.

These figures are stellar, but the testing conditions are not realistic.  In real-world usage, there are so many things that affect battery life.

During my first 10 days with this machine, I never got more than 8 hours and usually more like 7.  After much research & diagnostics, including a visit to the Genius Bar, I tried what all of you reading this must think is the obvious thing to try:  I turned down the screen brightness.  It turns out that you get a couple extra hours of battery life on 50% brightness compared to 80% brightness.  I can now get close to 10 hours, maybe a bit more.  I *prefer* having the screen brightness at 80%, and often leave it there while running on battery as long as I know I won't be away from an outlet for more than 6 hours.  But for those rare times when I do need maximum battery life, I know I can get it by dialing back screen brightness to 40-50%.

* Summary:  should you buy one?

Buy a retina MB Pro instead of an Air if you want a MUCH better display, more connectivity, a more powerful system, and don't mind an extra 1/2 pound relative to the 13" MB Air (or full pound relative to the 11" Air).

If you choose the 13" retina MBP, I'd encourage you to shop around for good deals on last year's model.  It has the same excellent screen, keyboard, design, and same exact weight and dimensions.  The 2014 model doesn't have the new force trackpad, but I think most people can easily live without this.  The new 2015 model is slightly faster, but I think most people won't notice the differences in every day usage--I wouldn't.  If you can save $300 by getting last year's model, that seems like a no-brainer to me.  I didn't do it because I'm a teacher, and with my education discount at the Apple online store I got a 2015 model for about the same price as the best deal I could find on last year's model.

I'm giving this one 4 stars because I bought this MacBook for audio production / Ableton but straight out of the box the latency is more than double what it is on my old MacBook Pro 2011 which is a major problem if your producing without an external audio device on the go.

2015 MacBook Pro 512 Samples - 30 MS Delay
2011 MacBook Pro 512 Samples  - 14.4 MS Delay

If you don't care about audio latency then you can disregard this concern. I'm going to talk to Apple and see if this is normal because if anything the latency should be much lower in a faster / newer system.

Despite being a Windows user for many years, I have to say the transition over to Apple was by far the best decision. The MacBook Pro 13 inch offers a beautiful Retina display that's wildly clear and vivid. This laptop is incredibly lightweight and slim (ultimately won me over after years of lugging around a whopping 5lb Levono). Some say the new force touch track-pad is inconvenient because of the "lightness of the click", where most users want the satisfaction of a physical click beneath their fingers. Personally, I love the convenience of lightly tapping vs downright clicking.

Amazon made finding a MacBook Pro within my budget easy! I settled on the 2015 version because it had all the specs I needed for home and work use. And after trying out the 2017 MacBook Pro in-store, I am happy with my decision. I HATE the new keyboard the newer version comes with. It's essentially flat. I understand trying to it slim it down but the user-error is so much higher! Not to mention, the TouchBar is just another gimmicky addition to the "future of Apple" (really not as effective as one would think). The 2015 version has the old keyboard with keys that you can actually type on without the fear of a typo every other word. The battery life (so far) is fairly true to the description and has lasted me 8 hours of constant use. I was skeptical to purchase a used laptop, especially one so pricey, but after some research of the better sellers, this laptop has exceeded my expectations.

I am a student at Iowa State University studying supply chain management. I got this computer over three years ago before starting my collegiate career. This review will discuss my good and bad experiences with this computer. I will start with the positives then the negatives, and ending with my recommendations for someone looking to buy this computer.
 Starting with the good, I've had almost no problems with the capabilities of this computer. It runs all the programs I need for school with ease such as JMP, Connect, and  Learnsmart. Also I occasionally play the game League of Legends which needs a substantial amount of processing power. The computer runs games with no problem except they tend to drain the battery quickly. Other than that I have had little problems with battery life. I usually have 4-5 apps open, several tabs open in safari, and stream music. While doing this the battery still lasts several hours even after 3 years of ownership. This computer also has more than enough storage space to last you several years. The 15 inch screen is great for watching movies and videos. The speakers on the computer produce good quality sound and are loud enough to fill a small room. Lastly the multi touch and side by side features are great for navigating through multiple windows and working on things that require two apps to be used.
 Now I will discuss the negatives of this computer. Although, the size enhances the viewing experience I have had more problems with it than anything. First of all it is heavy and is a pain lugging to class daily. It is cumbersome to use in class, it doesn't fit on most desks, and takes up a lot of table space. A couple years ago the laptop fell off my futon while it was open resulting in a broken screen. In total the damages cost me over $1,000.00, because the employee at the apple store strongly urged me to basically have the entire computer refurbished claiming there was "water residue" on the motherboard. After that I have been particularly careful with the computer, but I have noticed 2 of the screws on the bottom have fallen out since I had it repaired.
 Overall this computer preforms great, but the size is a nuance. If you are a person who plays a lot of games or someone who works with video software like Final Cut Pro I recommend this computer for you. If you are looking for a computer for business, school, or just to meet your basic computer needs I urge you to opt for the 13 inch computer.

I LOVED my 2011 MacBook Air. I LOVED my 2014 MacBook Pro. I was wildly excited to upgrade to the larger display and more powerful processors at the end of last year, finally having some extra money. It was a HUGE MISTAKE. The only significant change to the MacBook Pro line over that time was the implementation of the Touch Bar, which is a gimmick. Gimmicks I can deal with if everything else works, but it appears to have caused more harm than good. It is unresponsive, it makes it harder to work with function keys, it lacks the ESC key, which comes in handy far more often than you'd think. In addition to that, I've had more crashes, more hangups, more delays and more freezes than any previous model and when it is running, I can't tell a bit of difference in speed compared to the 2014 model I had used for years. I can understand a few bugs, but we're a year into the lifetime of the device now and I'm still waiting on fixes. It doesn't play well with 3rd party software (LastPass, Boxcryptor, LibreOffice, Microsoft Office) and it doesn't even run the basic software that well anymore (Preview and iTunes are both more finicky than previous iterations).

As of this afternoon I dropped almost $3000 on the new Surface Book because I've lost faith in Apple's ability to make a superior product. They've apparently gone all-in on fancy tablets and phones and forgot that some people actually do work on computers every now and then. It smacks of a company that hit a trillion in market share and got fat and lazy because of it. It's probably not "goodbye forever", but it certainly feels like "goodbye for the next three or four product cycles".

This is the most refined and intuitive laptop I have ever used (out of about 200 models).

Upsides:  It's built solid, fast, and just well made.  The screen is sealed with a gasket.  The touchpad is what all touchpads should be (the gestures make it awesome).  Very fast.  Excellent, clear screen.  I have too much to compliment on this to keep writing.

The keyboard is not what I really like (mechanical/chunky), but given it's a laptop, this keyboard is very easy to use and backlit white.

Downsides:  Don't plan on doing much gaming.  It did more than I thought through Steam and whatnot though.  Disk space is limited, but can be negated by using iCloud to selectively store things.  Gets too warm.  Gets hot when gaming.

If you have and love any iOS devices or if you are interested in MacOS at all, try to find a way to get your mitts on one.  Even seasoned Windows/DOS vets such as myself can like it.

Like many people here, I looked at both this model and the newer 2016 Mac Pro 13.3".  I tried both out in the Apple store---several times---and came to the conclusion that this 2015 model had more features that I wanted than the newer model.  Besides being $200 less than the new model, I liked that it allowed me to use my devices that use USB2 and USB3 ports---the new one doesn't unless you buy adapters.  it also has a bigger battery which on online tests show it gives roughly two hours more than the substantially smaller battery in the newer model.  Apple insists they both provide 10 hours (12 for iTunes on the 2015). This means I'll get more use per charge than if I got the smaller battery in the 2016 model.  The keyboard on this one is superior to the clackety one with little tactile feel on the 2016 model.  I've been a typist for 55 years and though I can type well on both keyboards, I prefer the softer, quieter and apparently more reliable scissor-type on the 2015 model.  Online issues seem to turn me off the new "butterfly" keyboard.  I also like the Touchpad on the 2015 model.  The oversized one on the 2016 seems to catch people's wrist movements and cause errors. The newer model is brighter, but I never go about 45% on my display so it would be lost on me.  One feature I do like about the new one is that it turns on when you open the lid...saves wear and tear on the Power On button.  The weight difference is less than half a pound so that was not an issue for me.  For me, the 128GB storage is more than sufficient.  On my iMac with 1TB, I still have only used 30GB with my iTunes, documents, apps, and security camera operations, so  I know 128GB will not get used in the years I have this.  The final positive of this 2015 model is the MagSafe plug...a blessing and to cut costs, Apple did away with that and the USB, HDMI ports on the smaller 2016 model.  As someone else said, this is likely the last fully compatible Mac Book as it seems Apple is paring down features and I wouldn't be surprised if the headphone jack will go next.

Update:  6/12/17:  Working perfectly.  Been getting approximately 11-12 hours per charge.  I don't do gaming but I surf and use iTunes and some security camera features.  Never gets warm either so I am thankful for that.  My military retailer matched another local retailer's price so got this for a bit over $1000.  Great laptop.

Background here is that I was an avid Apple user in the 80s.
But I fed up with the price it cost to upgrade the product as well as the software.
So I begrudgingly moved over to  the PC side .. which I have used for years.

I had been following the Apple/Mac products ever since but until recently, had not decided to make the move back.
When I got the chance to upgrade my laptop .. I ventured back to the MacBook Pro world and purchased this model after much research.

I was an avid PC user. I absolutely loved having my Acer aspire one netbook and a large desktop before they started to run VERY slow. I tried everything to resuscitate them, but alas, I decided it was time for an upgrade. Because I love the genetic software Macvector (keyword=mac), I decided to try out a macbook.

One of the first things I noticed after firing up this device was how quiet and effortlessly it performs all tasks that I ask of it.
Response is excellent.  NOTE:  I did opt with the 8GB RAM 128 GB HDD to save money.  But after using it for a few weeks now.
I would definitely should have upgraded to the higher end of these options.

Pros
------

- Battery life appears to be excellent
- Laptop is light (Granted I am used to the Dell Latitude Brick that I have to haul around for work)
- Love the trackpad (Much more versatile and effective than its PC counterpart and really cuts down on the need for a mouse)
- Performance and processing speed are bar none
- Generous Selection of ports (This is in reference to the newer model)
- Laptop is sleek and dare I say, sexy
- No need for as many dongles (Needed for the newer model)
- Price Point is much better than the newer model
- Still has fully set of function keys (Unlike the newer model)
- Apple Genius Bar (Invaluable)

Cons
-------
- No internal CD/DVD (So no burning unless you purchase an external drive)
- Retina Display is nice but not mind blowing as other have suggested
- Does not have the Touch Bar that you can get with the newer model (But in all honesty .. seems more gimmicky than actually useful)
- Not as slim or light as the newer model

On a personal note, I did a lot of research on this model as well as its newer competitor.
IMO, this model was faster than the newer model.  While the newer one is sleeker and feather light, this model is no slouch and I barely notice it on my backpack. I enjoy the processing speed of this model .. It seemed slightly faster in my testing than the newer model.  The newer features being offered did not seem to legitimize the price for the latest model.

All-in-all, I have been extremely satisfied so far with this purchase and am enjoying my not-so-cutting edge purchase.

It's been a while, but I realized I never reviewed this.  I'm a software engineer; I'm picky...and this thing rocks.  This is actually my FIRST mac!  My whole life, I've used PC's and PC laptops.  Right before I bought this thing...I was running into gigantic problems with bluetooth drivers.  I won't go into that-- but I decided Apple was worth a try because they build the hardware AND the software!

This laptop has a SSD (solid state drive).  If you think you're not a techie, that's fine...but this one thing is important.  These hard-drives are lightning fast, and they have no moving parts.  The entire computer is faster and more responsive because of this, and it'll last longer too!  I've always cared alot about RAM and CPU power, but a slow hard-drive creates a bottleneck that makes those things kinda useless.  Anyway, SSD drive is SPECIAL...if you don't buy this immediately, I have a few more sentences I guess:

The display is excellent.  The computer is thinner than you expect.  I've never had a single problem with it (almost 2 years).  It's easy to clean, it looks good, and its battery life is unmatched in the whole industry.  The battery life is another reason I decided Apple was worth a try!  The SOUND of these speakers is also better than any other laptop I've ever owned.  Please know I really love this laptop, and I can't recommend it highly enough.  I think the reason I never reviewed it....is because I've never looked back.  It's just perfect.

The best laptop ever. I've never used a MacBook before. I watched some videos on YouTube for the beginners. After that the transition was easy. I updated the operating system from El Capitan to the latest version of Sierra without any problems. I also installed sd card (Transcend 256 GB JetDrive Lite 330 Flash Expansion Card) designed for this laptop. The card doesn't stick out from the sd card slot. I use this sd card for Time Machine app (computer backup). I bought the Ethernet adaptor for $30 from the Apple Store. Actually I don't use it because this laptop catches my home wifi pretty easy. This laptop has all the necessary ports. This is the main reason why I bought it. I bought the brand new laptop sold as used with 512 gb of storage for $1500. It was worth every penny. Apple updates are easy. It is practically impossible to pick up any virus. The computer is very beautiful and very light. It flies, the downloads are fast. As I bought 13 inch model, it is very portable. The Retina display is stunning. I wish I switched to Mac before. I just love it! This little laptop will be my baby for many years. My advice: do not buy the basic model with minimum storage. Try to get as much memory as you can. You will not regret.

Lesson here is IF you purchase and Apple product from Amazon make sure that you put it through its paces within the first 28 days of the purchase of the unit, so if it's not working up to your expectations you can return it to Amazon.  The local Apple store wouldn't except the unit after the 31st day. Finally this is not my first Apple or Apple Product. It's 2017, right? Times are a-changin', right? No one needs those silly outdated things like USB-A ports, HDMI, and SD Card slots built into their laptops anymore with USB-C and Thunderbolt 3 Protocols being established in the tech industry, right? NO APPLE! JUST, NO!! WRONG WRONG WRONG. ESPECIALLY FOR A PRODUCT YOU LABEL "PRO"!! Being a PRO product in the laptop industry indicates that it is built in the interest of people such as myself who want to render video files, transfer photo albums, and more using their SD cards, hard drives both new and old, and so forth. Nixing the USB-A ports is something I can KIND OF forgive Apple for, given that USB-C is going to replace everything it is able to replace here given a half a decade, but the SD CARD SLOT! THE SD CARD SLOT!!!!!! WHAT HAVE YOU DONE APPLE!!! WHY???? OH MY GAWD WHY!!!!! Pardon my toddler temper tantrum, but I just had to release that pint up anger I have been distilling in the deepest catacombs of my patience for months and months. This review is going to be long and is intended to be as much a praise filled review for the 2015 MacBook Pro I purchased recently as it is an admonishment of the 2016 MacBook Pro. I am a nursing student and an up-and-coming YouTube reviewer and I decided it was time to buy something I could take to school with me every single day and do video editing work on that would be streamlined with my other Apple products. I live on the go. I eat fast food products (probably more than a nursing student should), sleep very little, do homework and study from the open of some coffee shops until they close, and write reviews and work on videos way more than I probably should given that I am supposed to be learning how to save peoples' lives and stuff. Thus, I set out with a $1300 dollar flexible budget to find the right Apple computer for me since I am already up to my eyeballs with joy over my 2017 Alienware 17 R4 PC back home and wanted to go in the direction of my other Apple products (call me a sheep for Apple if you want, but I think this review will prove that I am willing to call Apple on their bull and if you don't like Apple products than you should just go away, you are DEFINITELY reading the wrong review, bub ;). After doing lots of research, the 2016 MacBook Pro 13" base model seemed like a great choice for me. It sports a long 10-hour battery (so they say), is---patience of a 18th century Catholic school teacher---thin, and has all the latest and greatest Apple goodies built-in save for the touch bar (an entertaining addition at best, downright annoying at worst---many reviewers say). Alas, there were too many compromises made for Apple to make such unapparent dimensional and functional abilities manifest. The biggest for me that is not negotiable is that they executed the SD card slot!!! At least with the USB, HDMI, and MiniDisplay ports, we can huddle in a corner with our precious dongles and whisper into the empty night, "My... precioussssss..." and assure ourselves that someday we will be able to transition all of those items into actual USB-C replacement products. But Apple-- stinking, rotting, and losing its nutritional value Apple---decided that it was time to say, "Off with their heads!" like The Red Queen (and with as much sanity) to all of the poor, begging-for-mercy SD card slots in the MacBook Pro lineup; forcing usuntil death or sale or accident do we part---- to have to use an external adapter of some sort to read our SD cards. That. Was. So. Stupid. Of. Them. I feel completely confident in making up the statistic that 99.9% of all professional and semi-pro photographers use SD cards in their cameras or other equipment. The SD card is in no way obsolete, nor has current wireless technology replaced the intrinsic value of physical storage and transfer methods being hardwired into devices. I do not CARE that there are SD card readers that are USB-C compatible. When I am on the go doing film work or working on reviews, I do not want to have to worry about carting around 50 dongles!! Some smart reader might be thinking right now, "Well wait Bren, you said you have the 2017 Alienware 17 R4 and it doesn't have an SD card slot, why aren't you sad about that?". Because that PC is a 10 pound desktop replacement gaming laptop and it can gladly stay at home as it can afford to utilize a SD card reader as I already have 500 cables and adapters running from it in its usual dusty waiting spot (nursing student, remember? Its been a while since I have gamed :'( ). This summer when I use the Alienware laptop more, I might get occasionally annoyed that it does not have an SD card slot, but then I will more than likely remember that I have a Mac and switch to working on it anyways (oooooohhh, he said it Mac haters... 0.0). Even for the comparably Mac sized 2017 Razer Blade 14, I am disappointed but somewhat willing to forgive it of its lack of SD card slot as its primary purpose will be gaming for most buyers. But the MacBook Pro is a different story. It is a small, light, powerful device that until 2016 seemed custom fit for content creators, photographers, and other such lines of work or hobbies. Imagine this scenario because something like it WILL happen someday if you get the newest MacBook Pro: You are on a multi-day vacation or out for an all-day photoshoot having the time of your life. You sit down at some point to get some albums created and pics and videos uploaded from your camera when, "Oh NO!! SHOOT!!!. You have lost, forgotten, or had stolen your precious SD card reader! Now you are out of luck and that's all she wrote. Comment and tell me your solutions to this SD card reader dongleitis (not a real medical diagnosis, I am quoting MobileTechReviews' Lisa, there), but I will reply to every solution with, "But wouldn't it be better if it was just built in?". The vacation/school/work trip scenario applies to any other dongles you might, no will--have to use until your hand is forced by the market to replace every legacy port item in your arsenal. I saved $300.00 and bought this 2015 MacBook Pro Retina 13" on sale and I absolutely love it. Any gain in weight and thickness between this and its younger sibling are pretty much negligible to me. When you are on your next flight and your carry on is a half-pound over or slightly too thick, you are not going to say to yourself, "Aw shucks, I should have gone with the 2016 MacBook Pro!! What was I thinking?!". You are going to say, "Well, I guess grandma's Christmas jammies she knitted me last year could have gone in my checked suitcase on this leg of the trip!" 10 hours versus 9 on the 2015. An hour gain in battery life: For who? Doing what? When? Where? I get it, I really do. I spent 4 months trying to find a gaming laptop that could give me just 30 minutes more battery life in a coffee shop typing if I needed it and boost the battery life from 2 to 2-12 hours. But 9 hours versus 10? I really hope to our Lord in Heaven Above that you are never stuck glued to a chair in a wall outlet-less dessert of a room for that long. Or that you can't manage to turn south your upturned nose and just dim the light down or postpone that video transfer for an hour or if absolutely necessary. Better yet, the solution to the battery life drama resides in the hands of a company originating on Indiegogo called Omnicharge. Omnicharge | Omni 20 | A Portable Power Bank Charger for Laptops, Cameras, Phones, Smart devices and More | AC/HVDC Power Outlet | Fast-Charging USB Ports | 70W Adjustable DC Output | 20,400mAh I included pictures that show my beautiful 2015 MacBook Pro and the Omnicharge Omni 20 I just got recently. The Omni 20 is a portable power bank and the first of its kind that can charge this MacBook via the Mac charger hooked into the Omni 20s AC wall outlet port and with direct DC Output via a custom made Magsafe 2 cable the company sends you when you choose it during order as shown in one of the pictures!! I am not sponsored or compensated in any way for saying this, I was an early backer of the Omnicharge on Indiegogo and it has more than exceeded my expectations when I finally got it last week. It won tech of the year at CES 2017 and I will not be surprised when it appears on every major retail website including Best Buy, Newegg, and others, it is already available for purchase in the U.S on Amazon. It is expensive, but it is absolutely, positively worth it. If you buy this Macbook Pro on sale like I did, you can take the $300.00 you saved and buy an Omnicharge to get essentially 14 hours of battery life with your Mac!, buzz off 2016 MacBook Pro!! Check out my full-length review of it in the comments, I know you are going to want to consider it yourself as soon as you skip around in the table of contents I made for the video and see everything it can do, just note that at the time I filmed this I still had my 2015 MacBook Air. New Videos will be coming featuring my lovely MacBook pro!! I am going to link the Amazon page for it, I am not sure where it'll pop up in the review, so I hope it doesn't seem scammy! :D Overall, the point of all this drama is just to say that any stated gains in whatever whatevers the 2016 MacBook Pro 13" base model is trying to shove off on you just are not worth the sacrifices involved nor the snooty price premium you will pay for the latest-yet-not-greatest from Apple. This entire review was written at 3am in the dark on my lovely, perfect, streamlined, truly and honestly PRO MacBook product. The 2015 MacBook Pro Retina 13" base model from Apple. If you have made it this far in the review, then that means that this device has that much interest to you. Or I am just that good of a writer. Just buy it already for crying out loud!!!!! If this review made you laugh or helped you in any other way, please hit like so others can see it! Cheers! -TechRN

Review on the mid 2015 Baseline 15inch MacBook Pro.  Very disappointed.  Two primary areas that concerned me the most and what will prompt me to return.

Please note that I upgraded to the latest build of Sierra and I strongly believe this is what is causing it.  After a few days of use, the Battery life, not just reporting in activity monitor, but actual real world usage is not even better than my $700 dell (7559).  This thing can now only last less than 6 hours.

I'm not running Chrome, indexing is not occurring (I hate this BS excuse for Apple apologists), I'm at half brightness, just web browsing and nothing major is occurring in activity monitor to induce this.  This is unacceptable for a laptop that is $2K after taxes. A laptop that prides itself on exceptional battery in the 10 hour range on super light usage.

Lastly, the screen.  Yes, its been improved in 2016, but the overall quality is sooo underwhelming.  Looks dull and has poor viewing angles.

Advice.  Don't upgrade to Sierra and don't accept paying close to 2K for a product that is 2 years old in the apple line, with a mix of 3 and 4 year old hardware.

I Love this Macbook Pro! The only downside are the two Thunderbolt 2.0 ports on the left. I want to use them with my CDJs for deejaying but I can't find an adapter that goes from Thunderbolt 2.0 to a USB port.

I considered waiting for the 2017 gen MBP, and I'm glad I didn't.  It seems like this might be the last "good" MBP, unless Apple decides to change add back USB ports and the SD slot.  Sure, another generation back was arguably better, but I find this computer to be adequate to my needs right now (though it is a disappointment that I can't upgrade the RAM, which definitely limits the lifetime of how long this product will last).

It's nice and lightweight, the SD port is useful, and it's powerful enough for me to do fairly layer intensive graphic design work in Photoshop and basic grading in Lightroom.  The keys feel fantastic to type on.  The overall design is sleek and pleasing to look at and hold.  The force touch trackpad works great.  Overall, I feel this is the best laptop I've ever purchased or used.  It feels sturdy and reliable, both hardware and software-wise.

I needed a new Mac. I was waiting on the mini but Apple seems to have abandoned both the Pro and Mini.  So I waited for the October 27th MacBook event to see what the new MacBooks would offer.  I was sorely disappointed. The performance improvements were marginal at best and some of the other "improvements" were just plain mind boggling. The touch strip is a gadget that O can see quickly fading into a fad more than usefulness.  In an age of touch screens, why downgrade to merely a strip?  The USB-C ports are a terrible idea. I don't want to hear about "future-proof".  I have peripherals that I need to work with my MacBook right now.  They include a USB mouse, a Thunderbolt dock, an HDMI monitor, two USB 3 external hard drives, several USB 3 thumb drives, two Thunderbolt external drives, several SD cards from my cameras, an iPhone, an iPad and an iPod. I don't want to be forced to buy adapters to make all that work.

So, I stuck with the older retina MacBook but then had issues with quality control. I had to return two before I finally got one without issues right out the box. The first made clicking sounds during use.  Normally, that wouldn't bother me but in an all flash notebook, that's not a normal sound.  The second had severe light bleed around the edges and corners as well as a really bad mura spot.  Look Apple, if you're gonna charge us absurd prices for your hardware, at least make sure the QC is better. I literally feel like I'm paying for the Apple name at this point and nothing more.  Anyway, MacOS Sierra seems nice and stable so far. The 13" rMBP works with everything I have right out the box. I can charge and sync my Apple devices, access my external drives, access my digital camera photos, connect to my 27" external monitor and use an external mouse all without the need for a new dongle.  Processing power is more than sufficient because of the low overhead of MacOS. Remember, MacOS is made to work with the latest MacBooks which have 1.1-1.2 GHz CPUs.  That makes the 2.7GHz of the rMBP pretty zippy. It's not as thin and light as the newer MacBooks but it's not exactly what I would call thick and heavy.  It compares favorably in size and weight to my wife's Air.  Battery life isn't spectacular like it is with the Air but still better than my Windows laptop.  The display quality is okay but "retina" shows its age when compared to some other high-res screens like my Asus Zenbook.

I got my retina MacBook on sale for $400 less than the cheapest (non-touch bar) new Mac and $700 less than the cheapest touch bar enabled new Mac.  This will also likely be my last MacBook because the prices are beginning to get absurd, especially for what you get. I've been a Mac user for nearly a decade. This is my fourth Mac. If Apple keeps up this habit of radically increasing the prices while marginally increasing performance or, even worse, crippling their Macs (USB-C ports only), it definitely will be.

This is the last Apple MacBook that was actually good.  They ruined the 2016 model, so get this one.

The 2008 MacBook had a removeable battery, removable hard drive, IR receiver and a remote control, a battery indicator light, mag safe, and USB ports that were compatible with all the electronics I owned.

Bought this immediately after seeing the unveiling of the late 2016 model.  Losing the function keys for a toucher was a deal breaker.  I use those for too often to have them be virtualized, moving around or even unavailable.  The new one, while touted to be up to x faster, the numbers are based on the slowest 2015 and fastest 2016.  The base model went up in price $400, which excludes any performance benefits.  As a matter of fact, video is actually slower than this model, without the upgrade.  The only real upgrade for the new one, before adding on options is faster memory.

I run windows and linux VMs fairly regularly and while I could run them on a comparable Windows system, adding windows systems to an already portly windows system has never worked out well for me, so while disappointed in the new upgrades, this 2015 model still rocks VMs and does all I need it too for far less $$$.  While USB-C is cool, a bag full of dongles is not.  I prefer ports, especially the SD slot, which I do use regularly.  With real function keys, I don't worry about one vendor or another not upgrading fast enough and losing virtual function keys, so this model is golden.  Hope Apple puts back the function keys and keeps the touch strip too.  I could see it being useful for some things, but not a replacement for real function keys.

Anyway, if you are contemplating buying one of these and they are still available, do it.  They are great machines, even if the crowd loves to follow the blinky light!

My old MacBook (2009 13") finally gave up the ghost this summer and I needed a replacement. This macbook fit the bill--I didn't want to have to buy extra accessories just to plug in USB drives or headphones, like the regular MacBook, an the retina display Macbook Pro is slim and gorgeous. I love it. It arrived in great condition, and it's been working perfectly for me since I got it.

PROS:
- Can run Windows 10 via Bootcamp
- High resolution/dpi screen
- Thin and relatively lite weight

CONS:
- Ghosting issues on LCD screens on the first version of these laptops
- Coating rubbing off on LCD screens on the latest version of these laptops
- Thunderbolt ports loose; touching the cable or moving the connected peripherals causes the device to disconnect; both versions.
- Fans run more often on the latest version.

SUMMARY:
- For such a premium price, this is definitely the worst purchase quality wise that I have made. Thank goodness I was wise enough to purchase AppleCare; as I've had to utilize it 4 times so far ... 3 times for my original (first) version ... and once for my latest (replacement via AppleCare) version. The quality is terrible (both versions) for such a pricey product. I owned a 2009 Mac Pro and that was an exceptional machine; never a problem with it. This laptop however, is the exact opposite.

- There's an uncomfortable looseness to components inside when you shimmy the laptop side to side. It might be intentional.
- There's an unsettling bend on the left-hand rest that progresses into a crunch if you rest your elbow there. So far no issues.
- And, on a personal note; I'd prefer the clicks and Jedi touches be more sensitive. This is skin against glass/aluminum, in case someone forgot. Phones are touch and slide, think about it. Yes, I've changed my settings.

Otherwise, a fantastic piece. Performant, reliable, lightweight and well proportioned.

Since starting my current job in May, I've spent the majority of my waking hours in front of this thing. Here are my impressions:

The good:
- Retina display is so good you'll wonder how you ever used anything else
- Remarkably thin and light for all the power it packs
- Can drive three external monitors at once (two Thunderbolt/Mini DisplayPort+1 HDMI)
- Glowing fruit logo on lid assuages status anxiety

The bad:
- Retina display is so good you won't want to use anything else
- Battery life is mediocre for workI get 4-5 hours using Chrome, Slack, and Spotify
- Having only two USB ports is disappointing for a machine with "Pro" in its nameexpect to invest in a USB hub or connect peripherals through a monitor
- Disposable designthere's no way to upgrade the RAM and Apple has done all it can to block hard drive upgrades, which means faster obsolescence

Despite my objections to Apple's crass monopolistic practices, I can't deny that this is the best computer I've ever used, and its combination of display quality, fit and finish, and software integration remains the gold standard for a large laptop in 2016.

Overview
The MacBook Pro is a useful product that is very helpful in academic and work environments. Students will find that the operating system will run efficiently and productively. The computer is built to last, but remains lightweight and easy to transport. The start-up is very quick and content loads quickly, making it ideal for student use. You will find the MacBook Pro is convenient to use, and has many small features that add vast accessibility. If you own any other Apple products, the MacBook Pro can connect with them and using cloud-based storage, can communicate across devices.
The various short-cuts and tricks that the MacBook Pro has can be difficult to remember and use correctly, and the software is much different than that of a PC. However, once you are able to better navigate your way around a MacBook Pro, the short-cuts and tricks that this laptop has makes for a very efficient device. The operating system also varies, and though there can be some compatibility issues, a majority of software downloads include an option to download for Macs as compared to Windows. If you are looking to use a laptop for student use, this would likely be a great fit. Microsoft Office Suite can be used on a MacBook Pro, and though the layout is different, the functions remain the same and its unlikely you would need to use any other computer for any other software needs.

Durability
MacBook Pros are also well known for their lack of computer viruses, and as a student who requires a computer that runs smoothly, that is an incredibly important quality. To a student working on a paper late at night, the last they you would need is an error message or not being able to save your work. This is a rare occurrence on the MacBook Pro, which is very comforting. Its software is very durable, and the hardware reflects that as well. The MacBook Pro is sturdy and difficult to break. Unlike some other Apple Products, its very unlikely to have a crack in the screen or run into any physical problem. For those who commute with your laptops frequently, this physical durability is an important asset.

Price
The price of a MacBook Pro initially seems steep, but it is a very efficient, lasting computer. As a student, there is no negative aspect to the computer aside from the expense. You will likely pay no service fees and will have the computer for years to come. Ultimately, the MacBook Pro seems to be well worth the price tag.

Users
The MacBook Pro 2015 with retina display is an ideal product for many users. This MacBook excels in many areas making it a great general purpose laptop. Paragon users will heavily interact with different CPU intensive applications. This include word processors, video editing software, digital audio workstations, and others, which the 2015 MacBook Pro handles suitably.

Evaluation
I will evaluate the MacBook Pro on the criteria of its Hardware, Software, and Design. Specifically, how the hardware handles execution of applications, how responsive the software is, and how elegant the design is.

Hardware
When it comes to usability the MacBook really shines. Even multitasking the MacBook pro glides through execution and responds instantly to every click. Hiccups are rare occurrences, which are easily remedied by reopening or refreshing the application.  The battery is extremely long lasting. Even when multitasking you can expect six to eight hours of battery life.

Design
This MacBook Pro provides a stunning display and sleek design. The 4k screen is by far the most impressive feature. Switching between crisp clean screens makes the user experience much more enjoyable. The screen is embedded in a sleek sliver matte body with curved edges giving it a clean modern look. Using a machine that looks great makes you enjoy using it again and again. In addition to looking great it weighs three point five pounds making it very portable.

Software
OS X is specifically built for Apples computers so you're in good hands. OS X runs your applications in a lightweight manner making switching through them a breeze. Responses in applications are immediate and OS X makes interfacing smart and simplistic. Apple is always updating OS X making it more efficient so you will always have the best.

Cons
The price tag of thirteen hundred dollars is the biggest contention point. It may seem expensive, until exploring the marketplace for another quality laptop. A great user experience, elegant software, stunning design, and powerful hardware is seldom found elsewhere for a less or equal price.

Evaluation
Evaluating the MacBook Pro on the criteria of its Hardware, Software, and Design it excels in every category. Ive enjoyed my MacBook for a year now and its yet to disappoint. The mix of power and elegance that the MacBook Pro provides through its hardware and design makes using it seamless and enjoyable. Apple has had a long history of creating great products and the 2015 MacBook Pro is no exception to the tradition.

I just recently bought the MacBook Pro 13 inch and really like it.  Im a 21-year-old college student that uses it almost every day for about 6 months now.

The products ideal user is someone that has a lot going on and who needs a computer for multiple different purposes.  For example, if you're working on a homework assignment in the internet browser, writing a paper, on email, Facebook, all while having Netflix and Skype open at the same time, this is for you.  If you're using it to play computer games or do any intense image rendering I wouldnt suggest it just because there are other computers more powerful designed for that.  This is very easy to use and looks nice.  Its also really light which makes it easy to carry around somewhere like a college campus.  I was looking for a computer that was able to multi task with multiple desktops open at once, easy to use, compatible with programs like message, and looked good.

What this product is really good at is multitasking with different desktops open and not crashing or freezing.  Im able to have many desktop screens open working on completely different projects without it freezing.  The user interface is also the best in the industry and very clean and easy to use.  It looks nice and the life of the product before it becomes outdated is a lot longer than competing PCs.

The only downside to this is the price.  At about $1,200 it is a lot more than a PC but the use and benefits from it is well worth the price to me.  The only problem I have had with it is the USB port not working.  All it took to fix that was a quick trip to the Apple store for them to reset it and they were working again.  The customer service from Apple is amazing and will help fix any problems you may run into.  To wrap this up I think this is a great product if you do a lot of multitasking and like easy to use computers that are also able to do a lot.  Its also great because itll hold its value and the performance of it doesnt decline as fast as most PCs.

My MacBook Pro is the 2013 model. It is a 15 Retina with 256 GB of storage. I use it just about every day for either schoolwork or leisure. The products ideal user is someone who is going to use it everyday for one thing or another and most likely uses it intensively. Its not worth spending the money if you don't use it that frequently. The reason I gave it a 5 star rating is because I don't see many flaws. To rate something 4 stars I believe there should be a few apparent flaws that prevent it from being a 5 star.

Durability

The laptop itself is extremely durable. From incidentally falling off the bed to throwing a backpack with the computer in it, the laptop has stood the test. After three years, there have been no signs of wear and tear except for a few minor scratches that could have been prevented with a case. That being said, don't go throwing the computer on purpose because you think you can. It is still a computer, which is fragile and not indestructible.

Display

The Retina display is great for someone who is going to use the computer for storing and editing pictures or even streaming movies. It gives the computer an overall better picture. The 15 option makes it easier to have multiple documents up at once and be able to easily see them. This makes it easy for the typical college student researching for a paper to have the Internet up on one side and the document on the other.

Virus Resistance

Overall Apple products are good when it comes to not getting viruses. For as much as I use the laptop for surfing the web and streaming movies it has not gotten a virus during the three years it has been used. I had an HP laptop for about the same time period and it became so bogged down with viruses that it was almost unusable. Dont expect complete virus control with this Mac laptop but it should do a great job.

Overall

This laptop has done what has been asked of it and I applaud Apple for doing such a good job creating this product. Reiterating the fact above that this laptop is most likely not for the casual Facebook user once a week, it is designed for the user who is going to get the most out of it and use it to its full potential. If you really want a high quality laptop I suggest spending the money for this one though. Hopefully this review was of use to you in your decision to purchase or to not purchase this product.

Are you looking for a new computer for school? Well then this is the computer for you! I recently stepped up to this computer from my 2013 Macbook Pro, and have been pleasantly surprised with how much better this computer is than the last. The new computer is sleek, fast, and easy to use. If you do photography, then no problem! This computer is fast and has enough memory for all your photos and photography programs. The most important features on this computer that I enjoy are ease of use, memory, and performance. This computer has everything a student or photographer may need.

-Ease of Use
The new Macbook Pro with retina display is much easier to use than the later models. While it is quite a bit more expensive, its easier to work through projects and programs. The keys of the keyboard are easier to type on making papers much faster to work on. One flaw in the thin design of this computer is the lack of CD burner. For most people this probably wouldnt be much of a problem but if you like to burn music to CDs or photos to DVDs this can be an inconvenience. Thankfully they have an external CD burner available for purchase.

-Memory
While the memory you pay for depends on the model you get, the 512 GB flash storage is plenty for the average student. You won't need to be out purchasing expensive flash drives or hard drives to make up for the small storage of your computer. I currently use my 512 GB memory to store almost forty thousand pictures along with all of my schoolwork, and it still runs the same as when I first brought it home.

-Performance
Along with a larger memory this computer has a 2.9 GHz processer which is so fast you won't have to be waiting around for your computer anymore, your computer will be waiting for you. The faster processer will allow you to run computer programs faster with no slow waiting time. You won't have to wait for videos to buffer for schoolwork or Netflix anymore!

Con:
1. In about 3 weeks of adjusting to a mac, I, a window user, went through the hardest time of my life.
2. It is still getting used to, but after everything is programmed the way you like, it gets easier.
3. Lack of USB ports.
4. Dashboard. What is it for?

Overall:
I'm very satisfied with this product. Again, it is a product that a life-long Window user would hate and it takes so much time to get used to. I find my desktop to get cluttered easily, so I have to learn to work with Finder to manage my files. There are some things that I don't even use on this MacBook Pro like a dashboard. What is that? And having another desktop? MacBook pro can be more complicated then what was advertised. I thought MacBook was supposed to make things easier. It doesn't. In fact, it gets more complicated. For instance, you need to transfer photos on CDs to your client. You need to buy an external drive, download another app, and then you got to deal with Photos Library, which is a mess in its own. The keyboard is really getting used to, but thank God that I can use my PS2 adapter to use my very old Windows' keyboard to use the "DELETE" key, "HOME", "END", etc... However, after adapting my Logitech Mouse and my old Micro Innovations keyboard to the Mac, I'm liking this laptop. Why is this a 4 stars instead of a 1? It's because I can use all the programs I used on my Windows laptop on this MacBook. Now you may ask, why did I buy a Mac in the first place? My beautiful wife. Before I got married, I'm a Windows user and she's a Mac user. After 2 years married, I'm being converted.

Recommendable:
Yes, but it will take time for a Windows user.

Some people would like to believe Macbooks are overpriced. They're not. Windows laptops with similar specs come with a similar price tag. Performance on any ultrabook between $1000-$1500 is more or less the same. What makes the Macbook Pro stand out then? In the past, its premium construction served as a major selling point. Today, that's not the case. The build is still excellent, that hasn't changed. However, companies like Dell, HP, and even Microsoft have responded by constructing laptops with equally excellent builds. Apple's Macbooks still hold the crown for best trackpad. Windows-based laptops have made great strides in improving their trackpads but when your starting point is the base of Mt. Everest and your goal is, well, the top of Mt. Everest, the improvement doesn't mean much. If your primary interest lies in web surfing, you'll find the Macbook's superior trackpad to offer a far better experience. The last major area the Macbook stands out in is its operating system. How does it compare to Windows? You'll find the two are similar. Most of the things you were able to do in Windows you can do in OS X. Most of the things. Let's talk about the operating system.

OS X is far prettier than Windows. That might seem unimportant but this is what you see every time you open the lid. Simple things like the gaussian blur OS X applies to many of its program makes the experience feel more modern. An area that has consistently plagued Windows is its settings menu. Control panel is a mess. OS X's system preferences is a god send for anyone who's ever struggled with control panel's messy interface. Then there's the little quirks each operating system has. To keep this review from getting out of hand, I'll highlight the most annoying omissions from OS X.

1) There is no volume manager natively built-in. Don't ask me why Apple decided their users don't need the ability to control each application's volume. There is a solution. Volume Mixer. It costs $9. Yes, you need to spend $9 to incorporate a feature that's been a part of Windows for as long as I can remember. On the plus side, Volume Mixer is aesthetically better looking and more functional that Windows' volume manager but $9 is ridiculous.

2) Hitting the red X on an application minimizes the window. This one is the most puzzling quirk. You wouldn't expect Apple to have such a blaring redundancy in their software. The red X and yellow underscore do the same thing: Minimize the window you have open. Why do you need 2 buttons that do the same thing? And right next to each other, no less. RedQuits is a 3rd party application, like Volume Mixer, that fixes this. It's free too.

3) When you rename a file, Finder relocates you to the new location of that file. In Windows, if you click on the file next to the one you're renaming (or behind it), you can retain your place in the folder. This is useful when you're in a folder with a lot of files. Almost every 3rd party renaming tool is garbage and doesn't work how you would want it too. The only solution I found lies in a program called Renamer (or you can search Renamer 5). It's $20 base. Way too expensive for such a simple function but there's truly no alternative. They'll drop the price down to $15 after your trial.

Every issue I discovered has a solution. A couple of them cost money. But when you're spending this kind of money on a computer, what's $24 extra? Other minor differences vary among manufacturers. A couple of spec differences you'll find Apple consistently stands on top with is in battery and audio quality. Take the Dell XPS 13. It's battery can last a healthy 300 cycles before degradation. The Macbook Pro's battery lasts 1000 cycles before degradation. Audio quality is superb on the Mac. Better than on any computer I've heard prior (this is my first Mac).

Second MacBook Pro that completely fails within months, no warranty:  warning! I have spent nearly $5000 on two MacBook Pro in the last two years because after 20 years, Windows 8 gave me the rest, I was determined to never go back to Windows. Well, both Apple MacBook Pro notebooks  failed me within months. First one was bought in January 2014 in the US, within ten months the monitor was covered with vertical colored lines. I contacted online service in October that year, they told me to return it in the US. Well, I work in different foreign countries so I could not have it repaired since I did not return to the US in time. Fortunately, it was stolen not long after and the insurance paid for it. Since then I thought I had been unlucky this once, so I bought another MacBook Pro at Amazon in August 2015, albeit with less memory, for "only" $2400. Well, within 9 months, it turns itself off, doesn't start with the on/off button and the keyboard does not work anymore, so I'm using a Bluetooth external keyboard. As off today, it doesn't even work with that anymore, shuts itself down within minutes. Warranty? Ha! Forget it! I won't be in the US until it conveniently runs out. Apple? NEVER again. I hope a Linux  notebook will become more user friendly or I'll revert to Windows.

My husband bought this as an anniversary gift for me. I was thrilled. The Macbook was delivered late, last Monday, the 25th of July. By Tuesday, I was experiencing problems with the laptop disconnecting from the wifi. The reconnect to wifi would not work so, to reconnect, I had to restart the laptop. The next day was no better and by Thursday the connection would drop within minutes of log in and restarts. Thursday, I called Technical Support at Apple. The analyst was exceptional in her attempt to help resolve. We tried for three consecutive days, including  re-installing the software and Saturday evening, she walked me through a new install of the OS. My Dell Inspiron finally became unusable after 9 years.  I wanted a solid state drive and a change from the constant updates, virus worries, and problems in general with Windows so decided to spend more for a MAC.  For me, adapting to the differences between Windows and Apple has been frustrating and time-consuming.  On the plus side,  nothing beats the state-side customer support and the SSD.  There is no noise and best of all no heat.  It is very fast and I can open multiple windows without any lag.  I'm on and off this laptop daily and the battery lasts for hours and hours.  I thought I wanted a 17" screen but the 15.4" is more than adequate and the backlit keyboard is a must-have. On the minus side it has no internal cd/dvd drive, telephone port or ethernet port so I cannot fax or use my CDs until I buy these adaptors. Not having an internal CD/DVD drive is Apple's argument that it's lighter but  it's not as light as I think it should be.  I'd rather have the internal drive.  I'm not much in the way of games or videos but do a lot of web searches for information, etc. and use the Apple version of Word and Excel (Pages & Numbers).  These 2 apps are not as user friendly as their counterparts but I'm getting more familiar with them.  I've never had an Apple product before and I'm not sure if this will be my last.  After all, you can get an SSD with other laptops and there's something to be said about getting a computer that already comes with everything that you might need without having to spend more getting them.

I've used my early 2015 13" Retina MBP pretty intensively every day. I'm evaluating it relative to my 11" recent-year fully loaded MB Air and the most recent non-retina MB Pro, which I used for a year at work.

Here are my impressions of the 2015 rMBP so far, relative to these other Macbooks:

* Display

This is the main reason I bought the rMBP and I'm absolutely thrilled with it. It blows away every other Macbook's display except of course the 15" retina MB Pro. (The 15" Pro is too big and heavy for my needs, and is overdue for a refresh.) For years, I've been running my MB Airs with an external monitor, a pretty decent 25" 1080p IPS display, and I was happy with this setup. No more! The external monitor and obviously the MB Air's display are a major step down from the rMBP's display. I'm spoiled - it would be really hard for me to go back now that I'm used to the MBP's gorgeous high-res display.

* Weight

The 13" rMBP weighs 3.5 pounds. Whether that feels like a burden or a breeze will depend on what you're comparing it to.

I'm coming from a 2.4 pound 11" Macbook Air, which I brought with me almost everywhere, including to work every day. The extra pound of the 13" Pro is very noticeable. The weight of the pro was the only reason I hesitated choosing it over a 2015 MB Air.

If you're comparing the Pro to the 13" MB Air, the Pro is only 1/2 pound heavier. If you're comparing the Pro to similarly configured Windows laptops, many of which weigh 3 to 4 pounds, it's in the same ballpark in terms of size and weight. If you're comparing the Pro to the 13" non-Retina Macbook Pro (yes they still sell these), the non-Retina Pro weighs a full pound more than the 13" rMBP.

For me, the Pro's extra weight relative to the MB Air is a compromise I'm willing to make in order to have a much more powerful machine with a much better display. Plus, I no longer need to bring my laptop with me everywhere now; sometimes it's fine to just bring my iPad mini 2 and external keyboard. (It helps that MS Office is available on iPad now, and IMHO it's pretty good.)

* Force track pad

The "force" part -- pressing the track pad harder to activate different features -- is not supported in most applications now, but more and more applications will support it in the coming year. Until that happens, it works great as a regular trackpad - better than the (already excellent) trackpad on previous MB Pros and Airs. I like using the new trackpad pretty well. But it's not a killer feature, and in the future when more apps take advantage of it it will probably be like having a third mouse button--handy, but hardly essential.

* Speed & Performance

The 2015 rMBP has a newer generation of processor and graphics. Everything feels very fast, including bootup times, app startup, running apps, ripping music CDs, etc. That said, the 2014 model feels very fast, too, and I don't think most people will notice any speed improvements with the 2015 model over the 2014 model in normal everyday usage.

Apple claims the 2015 model's flash SSD is twice as fast as the SSD in the 2014 model. Independent testing from professional review sites have verified this. However, in normal usage, I don't notice much difference - the SSD in last year's model is pretty dang fast.

* Battery life

Apple claims 10 hours to a charge, compared with 9 hours on last year's model. Independent tests by professional reviewers largely support Apple's claim: Laptopmag.com reports 12 hours 4 minutes; PCMag.com gets 11 hours 10 minutes; CNET gets a whopping 15 hours 42 minutes.

These figures are stellar, but the testing conditions are not realistic. In real-world usage, there are so many things that affect battery life.

During my first 10 days with this machine, I never got more than 8 hours and usually more like 7. After much research & diagnostics, including a visit to the Genius Bar, I tried what all of you reading this must think is the obvious thing to try: I turned down the screen brightness. It turns out that you get a couple extra hours of battery life on 50% brightness compared to 80% brightness. I can now get close to 10 hours, maybe a bit more. I *prefer* having the screen brightness at 80%, and often leave it there while running on battery as long as I know I won't be away from an outlet for more than 6 hours. But for those rare times when I do need maximum battery life, I know I can get it by dialing back screen brightness to 40-50%.

* Summary: should you buy one?

Buy a retina MB Pro instead of an Air if you want a MUCH better display, more connectivity, a more powerful system, and don't mind an extra 1/2 pound relative to the 13" MB Air (or full pound relative to the 11" Air).

If you choose the 13" retina MBP, I'd encourage you to shop around for good deals on last year's model. It has the same excellent screen, keyboard, design, and same exact weight and dimensions. The 2014 model doesn't have the new force trackpad, but I think most people can easily live without this. The new 2015 model is slightly faster, but I think most people won't notice the differences in every day usage--I wouldn't. If you can save $300 by getting last year's model, that seems like a no-brainer to me. I didn't do it because I'm a teacher, and with my education discount at the Apple online store I got a 2015 model for about the same price as the best deal I could find on last year's model

BLUF: Excellent laptop in every regard. Keyboard and Force trackpad are simply unmatched. OS X is delightful, yet it is powerful enough to run Windows 10 and Linux virtual machines if you must.

I am a highly experienced IT with in-depth knowledge of Windows and Linux. I still dislike Apple policies and processes and refused to pay more for the same (Apple maintains a strict 30%+ profit margin). The last and only Apple device I owned before this MBP was an original iPod, because there were simply no better alternatives.

That being said, I love this MacBook Pro.

Due to an upcoming long-term business trip, I decided to get a new laptop computer in the 13-14" form factor. I had been eyeing the Dell XPS 13 and the Razer Blade Stealth. Dell and Razer have excellent laptops in many ways superior to this dated MBP design but also suffer from quality control problems, and lackluster keyboards and trackpads. After careful consideration and with full knowledge that a new MBP is expected in a couple of months, I decided to buy this laptop.

Again, I love it.

I just couldn't find a better alternative when it comes to quality. This thing feels solid throughout. Typing is a breeze. With every laptop I owned, I had been forced to rely on an external mouse when trackpad after trackpad failed to deliver an intuitive and reliable experience. That is not the case here. The Force Trackpad is marvelous.

After the easiest setup process ever, I have migrated all my important data, set up my wireless devices, set up automatic backups, and smart card compatibility. Let me tell you, the praise for OS X is not overstated. It is so simple. The more I learn about it the more I realize it just works! The transition from Windows to OS X was no big deal.

I have been using Windows 10 for over a year. Before that, I pushed through 8 and 8.1, and really missed 7. 10 is the best Windows out there. Microsoft really stepped it up and delivered. However, there are still bugs, blue screens of sadness, and all that jazz. There are still incompatible drivers, broken applications, and malware. You know, the things I have yet to experience on my short time driving OS X hard.

With the use of Parallels, I created the Windows 10 and Linux (Kali) virtual machines I use for work. The integration between OS X and Windows Parallels is amazing. I have tons of experience with virtualization: VMWare, Citrix, Microsoft, and Oracle flavors. They all have their strengths, but for productivity between Windows and OS X, nothing matches Parallels VMs in Coherence Mode. If you must use other OS as well, this is the way to go.

Keep in mind, the MacBook Pro line is due for a significant refresh. Apple is expected to release more details shortly and there are rumors that the new devices will be up for sale between FY16 Q3 and FY17 Q1. Not only is a refreshed design and a slimmer form factor expected, but also newer, faster, and more efficient processors, upgraded memory, replacement of F-Keys with an OLED display, and almighty Thunderbolt 3. If you can wait, you definitely should. If you can't, you can take a chance with the other manufacturers, or go for the solid and proven MBP line. I bet you won't be disappointed.

From the outside it remains the same, but inside, the 2015 MacBook Pro with Retina Display feels like its way ahead of last years (2014) model. Not only does the new MacBook perform better and has a longer battery charge, but also now has an ingenious touchpad that lets you do a lot more than just point and click. Aside from that, the MacBook Pro provides quality service that makes life a bit easier. Im a student and I choose to buy my first MacBook Pro back in 2010 because I found the programs to be quicker in loading and processing information on their OS. In addition, its design is simple but unique, as its weight, quite unnoticeable to me. Its been improving in all aspects since then and has made walks around campus or making yourself comfortable anywhere to use it, a lot easier. The features that the new MacBook Pro offers are amazing and to some extent, unbeatable. Firs off, my MacBook lasted about 5 years before it began to bother me with small viruses. Found myself saving money in that area with the MacBook while on my old laptop it was not the same scenario. Second, the home interface it simple but unique. While other PCs are customizable without having to hack it, the MacBook is still able provide a slick interface design; Starting at $1,299, the MacBook Pro is available in almost all tech related websites that are certified like, Amazon, Ebay, and Apple of course, and so on. Now some of these websites offer a better package but with a different or same price. Once you chose where to order it from, now its time to decided on how quick you want it to be delivered to you. There are usually three choices and I think most of these website offer them, Original delivery, 2-day delivery, and 1-day delivery. Of course the 2-day and 1-day can be quite expensive (vary on each website) but I prefer to have my items delivered to me as soon as possible. Like any other product out there, the MacBook has pros and cons. But I only found a few things in this area that I found reasonable to mention. The pros are that it has a bright display, fast hard drive speed, Innovative Force Touch trackpad, and very long battery life. As for the cons, its not as thin and light as competition, and the SD card sticks out when inserted. Overall the MacBook was worth buying because it provided me with great applications, learning experience, and is simply a must-have if you are in college. With a great Operating System and not having to spend much money on virus protection, the MacBook is convenient for everyone.
