I recently purchased this MacBook Pro to replace a 2011 year model and oh wow, what a difference! The screen is certainly the best reason to upgrade in case you are contemplating on doing this. With my old Macbook Pro I had to have the screen at a particular angle to see the picture properly or to see colors properly. Not so with this model. No matter how you have your screen angled, you will see the picture accurately and it looks awesome. I am a web designer and programmer by profession and it's very important to me to have a really good screen. The 15 inch size is wonderful and large enough to do my job right. Any smaller and I would feel cramped probably. I do my main work on my 27" iMac when it comes to doing graphic design work or development but just for doing maintenance and upgrades on websites, using Wordpress for example, I enjoy sitting on my couch with this laptop instead of at my desk. The trackpad is simply awesome as well. Yesterday I had to fix something on my neighbor's laptop, a Dell, and I got so frustrated because I'm so used to the Macbook's trackpad. On this PC laptop you couldn't click anywhere on the trackpad, only on the very bottom. Nor could I scroll up and down easily with that thing. With the Macbook trackpad you can use multiple finger gestures, for example just use two fingers simultaneously to scroll up or down. That is so much more intuitive than that PC's trackpad. For that reason alone I would switch from PC to a Mac. Not even mentioning working with Windows 10 versus OS El Capitan. Who are these Windows developers anyway that can't make anything straight forward? Now, I was very pleased that my new laptop already came with 16GB RAM. Most laptops still come with only 8GB of RAM. I have 32GB on my iMac but I can't say it's any faster than my new MacBook Pro. I have no negative comments on my Macbook Pro. Maybe it would have been nice to have a touch screen as well, but I'm okay without that because I own the iPad Pro 12.9" as well. You may wonder why I also got the MacBook Pro if I already own the big iPad. The answer is: there are still many things that I do, especially with my work, that are done easier on a real computer, but not necessarily by having to sit in my office. BTW if you are comparing or debating between a Windows touch screen laptop with a Macbook Pro without a touch screen. I will still recommend the Macbook Pro hands down!!! If quality and ease of use is important to you, there is no other choice. I use the iMac for creating and developing. I use my Macbook for personal things and for simple updates and maintenance on websites. I use my iPad Pro for entertainment, playing games, browsing amazon, traveling and much more. I love having exactly the right type of device when and where I need it. I know this Macbook Pro doesn't come cheap. But think of it as making a good investment. Macbook laptops last longer, hold better resale value, are of extremely good quality, and will never let you down. Using the OS operating system is a breeze. A quick story to end my review. A month ago a friend of mine who owned a Lenovo laptop asked me to erase data from her laptop. I thought, no big deal because how hard can it be? Well, it took me all day, just about. Of course not being used to Windows 10 didn't help, but in order to perform certain actions, I had to go all over the place on the computer to do them and often the screen would freeze on me (something that never happens on my iMac or Macbook). Nothing was straight forward. I kept having to ask Google how to do the simplest of tasks and the answers were always complicated. You'd think the control panel could handle all my requests but no, the Windows control panel is nothing like Settings or Preferences on an Apple device. About the quality of that Lenovo laptop itself. The screen wasn't half bad, I admit, but the keyboard was AWFUL!!!!!! Each time I pressed on a key, the entire keyboard moved down with it... it had a very plasticky and cheap feel. Get a Macbook Pro if you're in the market for a laptop. Even if you're coming from a Windows device. The transition isn't all that bad. If you own an older model of the Macbook Pro, I highly recommend upgrading because the screen will blow you away and the speed of this laptop is unsurpassed. Tip: it's a really good idea to get a case for this beautiful laptop. I did and it's fantastic. It's the Thule Vectros 15" MacBook Pro Retina Bumper (3203225) for $59 but it's well worth the price to protect your investment. It was very easy to put on and it looks really cool! So what are you waiting for? Take it from a professional. Just get this Macbook Pro!

My review is based on the fact that I got a pretty good value on this when it was selling for $200 less than normal. And still the case 3 months later.
I'm probably a bit biased on Macs since I'm a professional graphic designer, and it's just the industry standard. I've owned Apple computers for use for my business for over 25 years.

The benefits have remained pretty consistent in terms of Apple designing computers that are ahead of the curve, beautifully and thoughtfully designed  both in terms of industrial design as well as system architecture and ease of use. They are also built to last with quality being a major consideration in the design. I owned my previous Apple laptop for 7 years with no issues, with heavy use pretty much 40-60 hours a week. The only Apple computer to fail on me is a Powerbook that I spilled a full glass of Pinot Noir into.

If you're considering a switch from Windows based PCs to Apple computers, I'd probably recommend that you look at what you're going to use it for. What software do you need to run? What's your budget? etc.  These MacBook Pro computers are expensive. For some of us, even though they are more expensive, they still offer the better value. I think for others they are just buying into the brand.

If you're a student on a budget and just need a laptop to write papers and do general word processing, unless you're rich, a less expensive PC might be a better option for you. Spend the savings on something important, like food, rent, etc. If money isn't an option, you can't do much better than this. Again, it depends of what you want to do with it.

Powerful, small, and portable. I love the trackpad on this thing! It eliminates the need for an external mouse. The screen is just beautiful and very accurate as far as colors are concerned. I got about 7.5 hours of computing per charge, which is well more than what I need for a whole day of computing. Cons: can't run game on it; that's why I have an Asus ROG for gaming :) Very nice laptop!

What's not to like, it's an amazing machine. Beware that El Captian is a significant evolution and, if you waited a long time to update, much of your software may no longer be compatible. I checked with Roaring Apps for compatibility before hand but my Adobe 5.5 was not so functional as the site indicated it should be. I could limp along but not save anything. I ended up upgrading to the Adobe Cloud annual membership. It's all worth it. But understand when you buy this computer,  you can't go backwards to Yosemite or Mavericks. Intitially there were some bugs connecting to my iPad 2 ( yeah, I'm a Luddite) but the new El Capitan upgrade fixed that. The Wacom tablet (Intuos) works with a revised software download from the Wacom website. They say the toggle button on the stylus doesn't work but that broke off ages ago. Microsoft Office 8 is not compatible, 12 is...and so on and so forth.

I've had two windows laptops and both of them eventually suffered from many different issues on both structural and functional levels. I decided to make the switch to mac from reading that macs tend to have better reliability and build quality and bought the 2015 Macbook Pro 13.3 inch.

The macbook pro simply oozes with superb build quality. The metal unibody and inner parts are all seamless, form fitting, and tight together. I don't get the impression that things will be getting loose and janky like my previous laptops.

The trackpad is also superb. It is also metal instead of plastic and feels much nicer. Basic moving and scrolling is much more responsive and smooth. The mac specific gestures also work really well and are just as responsive and smooth. The vibration simulated trackpad click (featured on the 2015 model) feels more crisp and smooth compared to a mechanical trackpad and allows for even clicking responses and sensation throughout which is also nice. I found the extra "force touch" click to not be of much personal use and that it turned on when I didn't want it to when wanting to drag. I just turned the force touch click off and everything is fine now.

The display is great. Compared to other laptops, the colors are more rich, deep, and vibrant, and everything is nice and sharp.

The speakers produce a much nicer quality sound than on most other laptops, even at higher volumes.

The keyboard feels nice and clicky and is very responsive. It's also not too loud.

The magsafe charger definitely helps protect my macbook from falls because of its magnetic mechanism rather than being a mechanical mechanism. It's already saved my laptop from at least one potential fall. The red vs. green charging light on the charger itself is a nice touch. The charger also comes with an optional extension cord that fits into the charger, which I really like. The clips on the charger allow for wrapping of the cords for travel which is also nice.

Unfortunately, the hinge of the laptop has a plastic covering rather than being a seamless metal piece like current higher end windows laptops have. However, the long unibody plastic hinge placed in the middle seems and feels much more structurally sound than the small plastic hinges placed on either side that I had on my windows laptops.

Everything runs fast and smooth without a single hitch.

The macbook pro produces much less heat and noise than my previous laptops.

I always keep my charger on me and plugged into the laptop so battery life is not as important of a concern to me, but I appreciate that the macbook pro's long battery life will serve me well should I ever forget to bring my charger with me or I am not near a outlet. Because of it's energy efficiency, it's nice to know that I will not be damaging the battery by running it down as low as I would have to on other laptops.

The mac OS experience did take me some getting used to, but I found that it's still mostly similar to using windows and it works fine for my needs. For anything I'm confused about, I can easily find answers through Google searching. (For former windows users, I would recommend downloading RedQuits which allows for total closing of an application when you click "x" just like on Windows)

Overall, I really like my macbook pro and found that it was a great deal through Amazon Warehouse Deals.

This is my first Mac. After a brief period of adjustment I came to love the interface; it's much more intuitive and useful than Windows for the kind of work I do online. Yet, for all of those advantages, there appears to be both durability and customer service problems with Apple products worth considering.

First the durability problem: A fan failed after only two months, making a loud whirring and grinding sound whenever the computer was in use. I had bought the extended Apple Care package, and took the laptop into the Apple Store for service. They did not have the part in stock. So I would have to go back when the part arrived. I was told that they may be able to do the repair while I waited since it is only a 20-minute repair.

I got a message that the part arrived, and called to schedule my second appointment (second trip to the mall, second day wasted on a new, malfunctioning computer) for the repair. I arrived early for my appointment and was told to occupy myself for 30 minutes or so until my appointment time since they were busy. After wandering the mall with my broken MacBook for 30 minutes, I returned. At check-in I was told I didn't need an appointment since I was dropping my computer off for repair. I corrected them that I was waiting for them to complete the repair while I waited; they countered that this would not be possible and that I would have to leave the computer for the repair to be completed. By the way, be sure your data is backed up, because we might erase your harddrive while fixing this fan.

So I just called to see if any progress has been made. There was no record that any has been. I am to expect my 20-minute repair to be completed within 48 hours. I wonder if I will need an appointment to pick it up?

This is the best computer I've ever used, but I don't think it is for everyone.  Previously, I owned the 13" Retina version, which is probably a better choice for almost everyone.  It was a better size and weight, plenty of power, convenient and a joy to use.  But for me, I'm a research statistician working with large genetics files, I need major computing power and memory.  I frequently analyze data files  sized in the tens of GB.  Sometimes I run these analyses on a server cluster.  Even on the cluster, the run times are not exactly fast, but it works just fine.  This 15" MBP is indeed slower than the servers (how could it not be?), but it holds its own.  With four cores I can crunch through a lot of data at a quick pace, lots of memory for quick data access.  And if I run out of memory (a frequent occurrence), the new version of OS X will create virtual memory out of the super fast SSD.  Most computers will create this virtual memory, but will not do this when managing large files in R.  Now I can load a 50GB object into R and the computer runs just fine.

In short, if you are into heavy data analysis and want to do it on a laptop, this is the one for you.  GIS, Genomics, Medicare data, these files are BIG and need some powerful hardware, this computer is plenty sufficient, with plenty of leftover resources to run Office or Internet will the numbers are crunching.

This laptop is second Mac in our household. The earlier one was 11inch mac that we bought for my wife because she wanted something portable and light. At that time we looked for other options but it turned out that it was really the best.

Why I chose Macbook Pro 13 retina display -
1) Battery Life - After using numerous windows machines, I have to accept that they cant even come close to battery life of a macbook. Since this laptop is purely going to be used for work, I needed something which I can carry and don't have to charge all the time and I have to say that it doesn't disappoint. It has great battery life.

2) Trackpad - Oh boy, if any windows laptop can come even close to making a trackpad like the one mac has, I can switch in a heartbeat. Even the recent Windows surface book isn't as good as Mac trackpad. Now you might ask, ok but whats the big deal. The big deal is that since it is a laptop, you will be doing majority of stuff using trackpad and the smoothness and multitouch just makes things fast and easier with less steps involved. The trackpad enhances the laptop experience and makes you use your laptop with ease. Moreover since Mac & iOS and trackpad is made by apple, both operating system and hardware jells together is a harmony, resulting in excellent experience.

3) Design - I am not taking about this being pretty, my point is ruggedness. It feels solid, it feels premium, it feels a machine well made. And ofcourse it had good aesthetics. Very elegant.

Cons -
1) Memory hog - Man I cant believe my frustration that the OS is such a memory hog. I mean is freaking 8 GB of memory not enough. It has SSD with i5 and 8gb RAM, it should fly, but unfortunately no it wont. It slows down even if you have couple of applications open with few browser windows. Yes even with this small amount of stress. I have to constantly clean the memory with an app to make sure I can do stuff without slowing down. It is really frustrating.

2) OS - Mac OS looks pretty but there are so many things that need to be optimized. Safari utilizes so much memory. Basic work apps like MS office aren't optimized for mac. They have come a long way but still not as smooth as windows, of course. Apps won't shut down if you close the windows, you have to close by using command+q. I know people will say but man it has been like this with Macs, I understand but that doesn't mean Mac cant evolve. When I click on close, the process should shut down and free memory so as to keep the machine running at good speed. People say Macs don't crash, I am sorry it has happened to me on brand new mac after a use of few hours. Had to force restart.

3) Cost - Frankly they do cost a bit more than pcs with similar specs. The comparison would be apple to oranges but still if thats the case then I would expect a mac to be blazing fast at that cost which it isn't.

4) Customization - Unfortunately as of now you cant upgrade third party parts into Mac. So if you bought 128gb like me, you are stuck and bigger apple drives are firstly limited availability, they are used parts taken out of other macs and very expensive. Like super expensive. So you are really stuck with what you have. This is the problem with the 2015 model. I hope in future apple will release parts to customize and upgrade but as of now, sorry.

Final words - I like this laptop for lighter work and it suits the goal for which I bought this for. But this is not a perfect machine. It can surely improve. If you are looking for a stable laptop for work which is portable, had excellent battery life and easy to use due to its great touchpad, then please get this laptop.

If you are looking for a very powerful machine at the same price but aren't worried about weight, design or smoothness of trackpad, might as well go with windows options as there are many. Please mind that this will slow down eve with relatively lighter use.

I bought one over 4 weeks ago. 13inch, i5 and 256 GB ssd. My background has always been windows - been using it for 15 years. And I've used Windows 10 daily and extensively since it came out before switching.

Great Aesthetics:

First impressions, excellent looking laptop and very light! Ive owned an asus Vivobook prior to this Macbook and this one is pretty light in comparison. I LOVE the keyboard and the trackpad - I finally get it now why both of these have rave reviews.

Windows to Mac:

There's definitely many differences, especially with the keyboard shortcuts. You'll find that your fingers will have to get used to touching new key combinations which aren't as comfortable as with windows.

Transferring files from a non-iphone phone, like Android is extremely annoying. It's NOT plug and play. You will have to install applications on your phone and Mac to be able to do this. And even when you have these applications, it still isn't as convenient and straight forward as with windows.

The battery life is good - I get about 5-6 hours of non stop typing, with 3 browsers opened and wifi always on. Excel sheet, word and other apps opened.

Electric static. This is the most annoying thing. Everytime the charger is on the laptop, My left wrist will ALWAYS get stung when it touches the side of the chassis. Ive researched this and it is very common and apple says it's normal. Well, i've owned laptops from other brands and non of them showed potential of ELECTRICUTING me.

I didn't actually buy my MacBook Pro from Amazon, but I wanted to post a review on Amazon since this is where I make the majority of my purchases.

This MacBook Pro is one of the best purchasing decisions I've made in recent years. Is it pricey? Yes. But I'm of the opinion that it's better to pay more for something of good quality that will last for a while instead of having to buy a new "disposable" Windows computer for $200-300 every single year. Every Mac computer I ever had was replaced because I simply wanted to upgrade, not because there was anything wrong with the computer. In fact, they've always worked just as well on the last day I've used them as they did on the first day I got them.

I had been a Windows user until 2009 when I bought my first MacBook, the model that was all white and made of plastic. I thought it was the coolest looking computer ever. I also fell in love with OS X. A year and a half later, I bought the 2010 version of the 15" MacBook Pro. I used that MacBook until 2014 when, due to my own carelessness, the screen broke. I was a grad student at the time and although I was more than willing to throw down the money for a new MacBook Pro, I wasn't financially able to do so. Instead, I bought a Chromebook and used it for a year.

I respect Chrome OS, but it doesn't meet my needs. So a month ago, I bought a 2015 MacBook Pro retina 13", and I'm thrilled to be back in a Mac. With a Mac, I'm never worried about losing important files, crashes, or incompatible peripherals. When I had a Windows computer, it would frequently freeze up and I found myself Ctrl-Alt-Delete'ing several times per week. And I thought that was normal, but Mac OS X is in a totally different league.

The most difficult thing for a Windows user is going to be navigating the OS X. There's no 'Start' button, for one thing. Instead, you open the Finder and, from there, access your applications (programs) or your hard drive (like 'My Computer') where you can find all your files. But when you put aside the (very small) learning curve, this MacBook Pro--which is in the upper-middle range of the current Mac Pro lineup--is going to be faster, more powerful, and more reliable than ANY Windows computer that you'd buy for the same price and probably even more. When you consider the fact that Mac viruses are a rarity and that programs install more like apps rather than like trees that plant roots throughout your entire system, Mac OS X is naturally going to be a more stable computing experience. And I'm only really touching on the most basic benefits of this computer, without even getting into some of the more specific features or bells and whistles.

Put aside the fact that this computer is higher in quality and more reliable than just about any Windows house you'd find.. The retina screen means that actually using the computer is going to be an incredibly immersive experience. Videos, pictures, and even web-browsing is going to look stunning. The computer boots in about 15-20 seconds, the hard drive is incredibly peppy, and there's also the fact that the computer itself is well-made and looks sleek. Honestly, if you have the money to invest in this computer you'll be very happy that you did, even if you're currently a Windows user. There are countless YouTube tutorials and demos that will show you have to navigate and use Mac OS X, so don't let the learning curve scare you away. Think about it like this: If you were to buy a computer today, how long do you want that computer to last? If your answer is anything more than a year or two, buy this MacBook Pro (or even another model).

I bought the 2015 retina MBP with a 256 gb drive to do web development in mid December. It was my first Mac. I bought it because my Samsung laptop running Windows 10 was having trouble installing and running some Node.js tools: Grunt and Gulp. Those tools were essential to my web development. Because those tools were built to run in a Unix environment they never seemed to run properly in Windows: Constant install hassles and constant errors.

The MPB runs them with aplomb. They installed fast and ran with no errors on the first go. They just worked.

I was a bit worried about the transition from Windows (which I've been using since 3.1) but so far its been no problem. OSX is built on Unix, and I had some Linux experience, so dropping to the bash terminal (which is a pleasure to use) when I need to has been no problem at all. Other than that, things are named differently and live in different places than Windows, but some quick google searches have really helped me out.

As for the machine, its beautiful. Amazing build quality compared to the Samsungs, Lenovos, IBM ThinkPads and Toshibas I've used in the past. The machine boots in like 10 seconds and sleeps reliably when I close the lid (Something Windows laptops don't seem to get right.) The keyboard is nice. The force-touch trackpad is the best I've used. The retina screen makes me never want to go back. The machine is blazing fast, although I don't do any graphics intensive tasks like heavy Photoshopping or video editing. This speed is probably attributable to the very good hardware as well as the super-efficient operating system. I didn't need to install any drivers to get the machine to recognize my Android phone. The battery lasts at least 10 hours for me, about 9 if I'm streaming Netflix. I've stopped playing games so I can't speak to gaming performance or battery life. If I started playing games again, I'd probably want a Windows machine to do it on though.

Complaints I have: Time Machine seems to stall sometimes (Not for hours, I interrupt it and restart if it stalls for more than 5 or 10 minutes. I should probably just let it run but I'm impatient.) The speakers were a bit quiet for me so I installed Boom 2 volume booster. I can't get the HDMI out to display full screen on my TV (Probably a resolution incompatibility.) I wish the machine had at least one more USB port. (I have an inexpensive portable external monitor that uses USB. When I hook that up (Which is most of the time when I'm working at my desk,) I'm down to one port to plug in my external devices. I have to resort to a USB hub if I want to plug more than one thing in.)

Overall, I'm more than satisfied with the purchase so far. I won't be using Windows machines in the future unless I'm forced to by work or something. I fully expect this machine to last much longer than the average 2 years of a Windows PC.

I bought the new Apple MacBook Pro in August 2015. This is my second Apple laptop. The new Apple MacBook Pro is perfect for students and office use.

The new MacBook Pro still has some imperfections when comparing to other current popular laptop products, even though it is a powerful laptop for office and entertainment use.

Weaknesses and cons:

I bought the Mid 2014 version of this laptop from B&H. Having owned MacBooks since 2009-2012 (upgrading to the latest Macbook Pro each year) what Apple has done is phenomenal. A lot of people complained about no Ethernet ports but Apple has been an industry leader and knows the pulse of technology and market direction.
Pros -
Great design and the unibody design is timeless.
The dimensions and width make this laptop very portable and fits the airline trays comfortably.
Much better graphics processor than competing Windows laptops as it includes IRIS chips. Very few other machines have a 28W TDP chip.
Fast SSD makes operations a breeze.
The retina screen is a delight
Excellent battery life.

Cons -
I believe Apple can improve the screen resolution. When this machine was launched in 2012, a 1200x800 (times 2 for Retina) was great. To run a higher resolution there is extra load on the iGPU as it has to scale and display content. This causes some lag for data rich webpages or Facebook. Apple should increase the screen resolution to 2880x1440 or higher in the next iteration to give us more screen real estate.

Future Roadmap -
I'd like to see some of the enhancements from the rMB like thinner screen, terraced batteries brought into this machine.

Computers are used by all ages and I have no doubt the MacBook Pro with Retina Display is suitable for anyone. After my Sony Viao computer crashed in early November, I purchased the MacBook Pro with Retina Display on November 15, 2015 for around $1,500. As a college student it was certainly quite the investment. The computers I purchase are mainly utilized for word processing, PowerPoint displays and storage as well as speed.

I evaluated the Apple MacBook Pro with Retina Display with the most emphasis on speed of processing. It is obvious that an Internet connection can play a large role in the speed of a computer. As a result, I analyzed the computer when it was not connected to an Internet source. The Apple MacBook Pro with Retina Display is considerably faster than any other computer I have worked on. I was impressed, when running multiple programs at once as the computer never slows down.  The speed of the MacBook Pro is very noticeable when I am forced to use a laptop other than an Apple MacBook Pro with Retina Display.

Another main focus of my evaluation was of the availability technological support provided through Apple Inc. When first setting up my Apple MacBook Pro display, I had some complications with getting the computer synced with my iPhone. I contacted the Apple Technology Support and only was on hold for approximately three minutes before someone was happy to assist me. I was even more impressed by the Apple Support website, it includes the answer to any complication you can imagine.

My only slight criticism of the Apple MacBook Pro with Retina Display is that I personally do not think spending the extra money for the Retina Display provides any benefit. I have not been able to tell the difference in the resolution of the display when compared with a computer who lacks the Retina Display.

Overall I can still confidently say, I am impressed with the Apple MacBook Pro with Retina Display. I have been impressed not only by this product but also Apple Inc. as a company in general. I certainly am happy with my purchase!

I just turned 15 and needed a computer for my english class and then my CAD classes to do work from home so from the start i knew that i needed a very powerful computer that could be transferred from home to school and back on a daily basis (I also have divorced parents) so it needed to do a lot of traveling, anyway i settled on the macbook pro with retina display and for $1,299 it feels like they are giving it away.  This laptop is way better then i was expecting (This is my first mac and I'm NEVER going back to windows) My mac "just works" it has never disappointed, It wins in all departments over windows.  My mac has a metal body (Most high end windows are still made from plastic) that just shows how much more they are interested in money than quality.

Fully loaded MacBook pro was provided to me to replace the MacBook Air standard company issue that began wheezing after a few days. Evidently the Core i7 chip in the MacBook Air is only a TWO CORE CHIP. I didn't even realize Intel made a 2 core Core i7. Nice marketing trick on Apple's part.

Back to the MB Pro.

My setup. MB Pro 2.5GHz, 256GB storage, 16GB memory, 2 thunderbolt displays, magic mouse, wireless keyboard.
Total cost? $4500.00.

Felt excited to be getting a new premier piece from Apple even though I've been on PC my whole life. So impressed with my iPhone 4S and 6 plus that was guardedly very optimistic. What a disappointment.

What prompted me to finally review? My track pad just failed right at the 1 year mark. Call our outsource tech support and he said it's a VERY common failure on these units. Can either build a whole new machine and ship it to me, or send mine back for days while it's worked on. Relying only on mouse while i consider how much disruption i can handle in my business.

Call apple care about it and they tell me it's something that could be fixed in a couple of hours on site and to just make a genius bar appointment. Make the appointment for 5 pm on a Friday, hire a baby sitter (closest apple store is 40 minutes away) and decide to make an evening of it; drop machine, grab dinner, maybe even a show, pick up machine before 9. problem solved.

Would that it were that easy. End up in a traffic jam and will inevitably be late. Call the store to let them know we are running late, they say that we basically are giving up our appointment and will be considered a walk in. Awesome. Get to the store and they get us in queue. Mercifully we are up to the counter in no more than 5 minutes.

Get to the Mac Genius, an extremely sympathetic and knowledgable soul, who says that regrettably they have to order the parts, they never carry then in store and that it's a 3-5 business day wait. Given that i was on a trip out of town the following Tuesday that would require use of my laptop, not a viable option. Not only that, to replace the track pad you have to replace the entire "top case" of the keyboard part of the unit meaning that I will get all new; trackpad, top case enclosure, speakers, keyboard, and battery. What? just to replace the trackpad? I've worked on laptops plenty and that is extraordinarily poor design from a maintenance standpoint.  That's akin to saying that the starter went out on your BMW, and they are going to have to replace the car from the windshield forward. Awesome.

The genius did call the store closest to where I would be staying and said I could bring it in there and they would order the parts and it should only be a one day wait. Still not viable, but I appreciated the effort. He also said this was the 7th apple care bad advice disaster of the evening.

So, out the store we went to ponder our options.

I'm going to have our integrator order me an all new machine, transfer everything over and send this one back.

So my question is, what am i paying $2500 for if something as established as a trackpad is going to fail after a year and require a virtual overhaul of the machine? is it the accurate support information i receive from apple care? not so much.

Now the machine has started staying on when i close the lid and draining the battery. Awesome.

And finally and surprisingly, the keys on the keyboard leave visible marring on the screen. Really? Such fantastic design from a closed ecosystem.

I have heard so much hype about 1) the Mac Ecosystem and 2) the incredible quality of the hardware. Not my experience at all.

The machine I moved from was a plastic case Dell with a core i5 and 8 GB of ram that I picked up for $379. I dropped a $100 SSD in it and that thing positive smokes this macbook for speed. Outlook never bogs it down nor does anything else for that matter. My MB Pro with a hotter chip and double the memory however has the fans spinning up all the time to handle the work load. If you have a large Outlook mailbox, good luck on the MB Air. Outlook makes it slow? Really? Shouldn't that be Photoshop or something....  Shouldn't something that costs 6 times as much do just a little better than that?

And a word on the OS. OSX sucks. plain and simple. programs hang up all the time. Using Apple's own Keynote gets the spinning wheel all the time. Ironically our marketing lead uses a 2013 Mac Pro with Xeon processors, 32 GB of memory. She says she gets the spinning wheel ALL THE TIME. It has a force quit feature for programs. If the OS was so stable and amazing, why would you need easy access to a force quit option? Trust me, you'll need it. Frequently.

And if you're using this for work, good luck. A huge array of enterprise applications simply don't integrate very well with OSX, or don't integrate at all. Migrating to Mac meant using Office for the Mac (2-3 years behind the PC Office dev curve), lose Lync altogether (amazing, amazing program), gotomeeting sucks on it, safari doesn't integrate with our CRM, the list goes on and on.

There are some cool features that you won't find in a pc to be sure; scroll on a non active window, the 2 and 3 finger gestures on the trackpad, swiping on the magic mouse, etc. And the hardware is sexy and well sorted. Ports grouped together, fit&finish, aluminum, etc.

But the feature coolness ends there. The magic mouse is sized for a toddle (i'm 6' 3" with huge hands. It feels like i'm navigating with a nearly depleted bar of soap.), there is no wireless keyboard option with a key pad, only a wired option. really? The wireless trackpad sucks to high heaven. The magic mouse continually loses connectivity across every magic mouse. My logitech optical mouse that i'm using as backup works flawlessly every time. 4 years old. perfect. rechargable battery even. Better have air conditioning (we do) because the Thunderbolt displays feel like heaters on your desk.

As a company, we have had to rebuild machine after machine after machine as the hardware and OS fail.

Getting this machine wasn't my decision and if it was, i would send it all back, by all new PC equipment with a robust support package, and bank thousands of dollars in savings and much more in lost productivity.

Note: I am not an Apple hater. I have an iPhone that I love and an Apple Watch that I strongly like.

Pros: Attractive, solid fit and finish, sexy backlit keyboard, retina display, fit in at Starbucks, lets anyone who walks in your office know that you're the man, Impress everyone else sitting at a coffee shop that isn't Starbucks.

Cons: hardware reliability, extreme cost (at least 4 times too expensive), applecare not competent (pushes most issues on the store so better be close to one unless you want to be without your machine for weeks at a time), integration with enterprise applications, keyboard mars the screen (?!?), impossible for any but the most sophisticated user to work on and voids the warranty anyway, magic mouse not so magic, not nearly as fast as hardware would indicate.

Final note: hats off to the team at the Spokane Apple Store. They were genuinely concerned and did their best to address my issues. They even called to follow up to see how things ended. Apple Care didn't bother.
Very disappointed w/it. Difficulty with trying to access sign in, and machine was loaded with other programs from the previous owner. Feel they should have been taken out.

Let me preface this with the fact that my boyfriend gave me this computer, as I wouldn't be able to afford over $1,000 for a Macbook on its own. That being said, I don't think I could ever go back to Windows after having this computer. The speed, the simplicity, the beautiful screen... it's all neatly wrapped into one extremely polished package. I'll lay out the pros and cons for my personal use:

Pros:
-Fast. This thing boots up in about a minute, and from then on it's ready to go. Open the lid and you're greeted with your login screen instantly. It reminds me of my Chromebook, which I always praised for letting you get straight to work upon opening the lid. Apps open quickly, and switching between them is effortless and without a hiccup. Which brings me to my second pro;
-Gesture based touchpad. It's very similar to an iPad. Three finger swipe between apps, two finger scroll, pinch to zoom- it's all here. It feels natural. And it makes navigation a breeze. It's light years ahead of windows computers, and I have to say that it makes it difficult to go back to a PC and navigate.
-Battery. The Macbook Pro is rated at about 8 hours of constant use, and I'd say I get about that. Although I never have used it for 8 hours in a row, it lasts about a day or 2 of mixed usage, depending on what I'm doing. Obviously if I'm playing WoW (which it runs fun on medium settings), the battery will run out in about 3 hours. But mixed web browsing gives me around 7-8, which is impressive for a laptop this powerful. And the magsafe cable prevents accidental falls, which I appreciate.
-Keyboard. The backlit keys are easy to see, and give a nice tactile "click" when pressed. Writing is fast and I make few errors. I love this keyboard.
-Screen, screen, screen! The retina display is simply gorgeous. Viewing angles are fantastic, color reproduction is accurate, and everything looks very crisp and clean. Another reason why it's tough to go back to my basic 1366x768 windows and Chromebook displays.
-Portability. With Apple's decision to remove the disc drive, the Macbook Pro has gotten pretty slim and lightweight. I can easily pack it in my backpack and slide it out when I need it. It doesn't break my back like my old fat HP, and it still retains 90% of the function. If you really want a disc drive, you can buy a slim external Samsung for about $30 here on amazon. I personally like this tradeoff.
-OS X El Capitan. This operating system has me enamored. It's so beautiful, clean, highly polished, and full of potential. If I can't find something (being a new Mac user), I can almost always find it from the Spotlight Search. The user experience is the most important thing in a computer, and I think that OS X has every other OS beaten in terms of usability, style, simplicity, and capability.

Cons:
-Speakers. They're just... not good. They're tinny, they have zero bass, and they don't get particularly loud. My $150 Acer Chromebook 720 absolutely murders the Macbook on sound quality. I was hoping for more from a $1300 computer.
-Webcam. It's just so-so. With all the focus Apple put on "Facetime HD" cameras on iPhones, you'd think that they'd bump up the resolution and quality of the webcam. But it remains useable. Just invest in an external HD cam if you plan on recording for youtube, blogging, etc.
-Ports. Who uses thunderbolt? Coming from a PC, I would like at least 3 USB 3.0 ports on a laptop. This has 2, which is sufficient, but I can't help wanting a 3rd instead of having 2 thunderbolt ports. An ethernet jack would have been nice, too. But we all know Apple likes their minimalism (The 2015 Macbook has 1 singular port for everything), so I'll take what I can get. Data transfer speeds are still good, and it juices my iPhone up at a relatively brisk 1.1 amps.
-Price. And this is the main defining factor in getting a Mac. You can almost always find a Windows PC in the same price range with better technical specifications. However, you're not paying just for specs, you're paying for the experience. OS X is much different than Windows, and in my opinion, more fun and engaging. Does that justify the price? On its own, no. But combined with every other pro, I think it does.

The Macbook Pro Retina overall is a pleasure to use. Things feel natural, fluid, and connected. Much like using an iPhone or iPad, everything feels polished. Sure, there are some hiccups here and there, but they're few and far in between compared to how many times I've had to deal with "(insert program here) is not responding. End now?" only to have the program hang there for another few minutes. Just know that specs aren't everything, and you should head down to your local Best Buy to try a Mac out before making the jump. Feel it out, see how you like it, and give it a chance. You won't be disappointed.

The quality and performance are great; the longevity of Macs in our home is impressive. Unfortunately, the inability to upgrade the recent lines of Macbooks may decrease their longevity. Disappointed in reliability: used in a small business operated by my wife.

The "ssd drive" is not user replaceable. This would not be a big problem except that the SSD has not proven reliable. She found out the hard way after 18 months - the 1 year limited warrantee expired - that people are finding the SSD failure a common problem (the Apple support representative explained during the support call that it even happened to them).

The idea was to pay extra for an Apple product to gain reliability. Sorely disappointed.  Yes, one can pay even 20% more for the computer and add AppleCare to the cost to extend the warrantee period, but the price point being what it is, wouldn't you think Apple would (a) use especially high quality components to start and (b) warrantee them for more than 12 months? Despite the repair costs, the down-time associated with losing the use of the computer is costly in a number of other ways. The impact of poor reliability is indeed very high.

If known ahead of time, we would have not purchased this machine.  We have owned laptops of equal performance from other manufacturers at substantially lower price points and found them quite reliable, and even more importantly, self-serviceable.

The name doesn't mean everything....I love Apple products but they have honestly SO many unnecessary glitches. Not only did I buy this computer once and had a start-up issue, but when I exchanged it, I had the same issue for both!

I, like some others, was stuck on the "Setting up Your Mac.." screen right when I tried to set the computer up, so I tried to reboot it and a circle with a line through it was displayed on my computer. I called Apple, and they basically told me that my hard drive was corrupt and I should return the computer. (Great.)

So I exchanged this laptop for the same model, and when I went to set it up, AGAIN, I was shown the "Setting up your Mac" screen for another three hours. I called Apple to see what the problem was because I didn't want to "screw it up" again or even touch my computer for that matter. I thought maybe it was something with my Internet connection, but my WiFi is fine, and my laptop was nearly on top of the router. The Apple specialist on the phone told me the only fix for my "slow set-up" was to plug an ethernet cord into the laptop and connect directly to my router. (Then he told me the MacBook pro actually doesn't have an ethernet port but a 'Thunder Bolt' port?)

When I asked if this was normal to take hours to set up, to their admittance, they told me, "No." It may have been because I entered in my iCloud username, but my screen was frozen like this, nonetheless.

The Apple specialist told me to reboot the computer, and from there I was shown a screen with a circle and a line through it (again). Transferring me to a senior associate who luckily guided me, I had to, then, erase MacIntosh HD and then re-install the OS for a total of another two hours. FINALLY the actual set-up process took a mere five minutes after that! Not to mention, I only figured all of this out because I talked with one of the senior associates. (Even so, we had to go through about five different techniques to even remotely solve the problem.)

My computer is fine now, and I love it, but seriously? For spending $1200 plus tax, I shouldn't have to spend nine hours trying to set up my computer. Not to mention, I could have done the same thing I did to the first computer because the second computer had the EXACT same issue.

I'm terrified to install any other updates after this! I'm not sure whether the Yosemite OS was the problem, but come on, Apple, I could have spent a fraction of the price for a computer that actually WORKED. Loved spending my weekend trying to set this computer up.

Let me preface this by saying that I'm 27 and up until a few months ago, have never owned a Mac, other than for a few months as a work computer.  I've owned around 5 or 6 PC laptops.

I was recently in the market for a new laptop again, as my Dell had gone kaput.  I wanted to get a MBP, but it was too expensive.  So I got a Dell...and returned it 3 days later.  It was big, clunky, and laggy.  I got an ASUS, returned in 2 days later.  Same problems, and it just didn't feel nice.

Finally, I decided...screw it.  Yes, it's more expensive.  But this is my primary tool to make a living (I work for myself), and my primary tool for entertainment.  I ponied up about $500 more than I was initially willing to spend and bought this computer.

I've owned this puppy for 2 months folks, and let me tell you, it has been the best purchase of my life.  Not for one second, do I regret this.

Why?

It does not hang.  It does not crash.  It does not lag.  It does not stutter, even for a millisecond.  When I insert an HDMI cable, it instantly splits the display between two screens.  No lag time.  When I remove the HDMI cable, it moves the display back to one screen.  No lag time.  No crashes.

Want to open Photoshop, Excel, Garage Band, Quicktime, iTunes, Chrome, Steam, Skype, and Spotify at the same time?  Please do.  Aside from Photoshop and Garage Band (which take about 6 and 4 seconds respectively to open), everything else opens instantly.  Want to switch between Photoshop and iTunes, then back to Excel, then to Spotify?  You can do it, instantly, with the swipe of  two finger.  No lag.  No delays.

As hard as I try, as much as I do, I cannot get this darn machine to even sputter, lag, stutter, or trip.  For even a millisecond.  Everything is silky, buttery, smooth.

Using the computer is an absolute joy.  I'd compare it to driving a luxury vehicle.  It's an "experience" more so than just a machine.

And don't even get me started on the trackpad.  I've never used anything like it.  The trackpads on PC laptops are absolute garbage compared to this beauty.  Half the time I'm using this thing with my USB mouse plugged in, I forget to use the mouse, and 2 hours later, I notice that I've been using the trackpad the whole time!

Because of the disgustingly quick SSD...boot up and shutdown takes about 10 seconds.  Going to sleep and waking it up is instantaneous.  At night, I put this thing to sleep by closing the screen. I wake up in the morning, open my screen, and my computer instantly powers on (I don't even have to press a button).  It's beautiful, and such an amazing departure from a 45 second Windows boot screen.

And battery life?  Over 10 hours.  It's freaking insane.

Folks, let me put it this way.  Can you get a computer with the same "Specs" for 400 less?  I'm sure you could, just like you can get a car with the same "specs" as a BMW for $25,000.

Do these computers even come close to matching the experience of a Mac?  Absolutely not even close.  If you want a computer that just WORKS, that will never lag, that will never stutter, that will never hang, and that is designed for maximum usability and convenience for the user, I highly suggest this computer.
What can I say it's a Mac! There is no better computer on the market than this computer. you will not be disappointed

Bought the 13" i5 with the 256GB SSD. Have been using the Dell XPS 13 i5 256GB that came out at the same time as this model since March and have been using this MBP for over two weeks straight now, so it is not a completely fair comparison. I have traditionally been a PC user, but did have a late 2007 white macbook from '07 to '10 and it was my main computer during that time. Then it was work-issued latitudes and think pads for a while until I picked up the XPS13 and now the early 2015 13" MBP.
I think the MBP ticks off more of the nice-to-have boxes for me than the XPS13 overall. They are both really nice machines.
1. The XPS13 runs cooler on the lap than the MBP, which is really nice in the evenings. Not a huge deal as I usually have them on a desk. The MBP does not run as hot as my old white MB did.
2. The battery life is really pretty comparable (slightly more with the MBP, and I can obtain info on app energy usage a bit easier IMO).
3. The keyboards are both nice to type on. I prefer the XPS as I make less errors on it, and the rubberized palm rest area is really nice and more comfy than the aluminum. The backlighting is comparable, but the MBP gets brighter.
4. The processors are comparable, and Adobe premiere elements (my test case) works admirably with either. The SSD is smoking fast in the MBP and it is noticeable with larger file transfers.
5. The speakers are better on the XPS IMO, but who really wants to listen to stuff for very long through laptop speakers.
6.  The thunderbolt ports are a nice thing to have on the MBP, and I feel are more versatile than the ports on the XPS. No HDMI on the XPS, which is not an issue for me, but may be for some.
7. Oh the displays, they each get it partially right, but I'd pick the MBP over the XPS. The MBP display brighter, and the the IPS is sooo nice compared to the XPS (I have the FHD version). I prefer the display aspect ratio on the XPS (shorter, wider) than the MBP, especially when you have side-by-side windows like I often do. The bezel on the XPS is non existent, which is nice, but honestly not that big a deal. I kind of like the black trim around the MBP which adds a buffer between the screen and any distracting background images/colors.
8. The trackpad is the ultimate difference-maker for me. I tried really hard to like the XPS trackpad, and it is indeed the best trackpad on a PC that I've had. But the touch and move delay and lower sensitivity is an issue. The MBP trackpad is best in class and if you are not using a mouse, this makes a huge difference. I don't care for the deep click force touch, but love the lack of a hinge which means I can press anywhere with the same pressure to register a click. And I can make the force required to register a click lighter or firmer. Just love it.
9. The XPS is lighter and smaller and a pleasure to carry around. The weight difference is noticeable, but I don't travel, and I remember the old bricks I had in the late 90s, early 00s that make these two seem like feathers. So weight is not a huge issue for me. The MBP 13" is plenty mobile.
10. I won't get into OS and software in too much detail, but the #1 thing for me is the ability of the Mac OS to properly scale applications for the retina screen. This is still an issue in Windows 10 (I've been using Win10 for 4 months on the XPS) and extremely frustrating to see blurry images/text/windows on a high DPI screen. I really like what MS has done with Win10, and would prefer it slightly over OS X El Capitan if it weren't for the scaling thing (which in Windows is more dependent on the app developers more so than in Mac OS from what I understand). I have Office 2016 on the MBP and it not as nice as Office in Win10, but getting really close. The one drawback is that it uses more energy than most apps on the MBP (especially Word, not so much with Excel or PPT), so I've been using Google Docs/Drive in Safari (Chrome is also an energy hog) if I'm away from a power source and the task is light enough. Adobe apps are also power hogs, but that is to be expected. I like the Adobe apps better in Mac OS than in Win10. I think the design in Win10 is flatter and more appealing, but that is personal preference. I also feel like Apple hides too much under the hood from the user, but I suppose you can still work around that if you are so inclined.
11. An unexpected benefit for me has been the iPhone/MBP integration. I love the airdrop and receiving iMessages on my MBP (although it can cut into productivity if you're not careful).
Overall, it's a great machine and I prefer it over the XPS13. It'll be interesting to see what the revisions are in 2016, but I was worried about the shallow keys of the new macbook making their way to the MBP and the loss of port options with a new revision, so I am very happy to have this now.
Apple has come along way since the old Macintosh SE I used in junior high around 1990, haha.

THIS WAS MY VERY FIRST MAC ... I have been a PC user all my life and had wanted to try converting to a Mac for years.  I've only had this Apple Macbook Pro for a week, but let me tell you that on day one I fell in love with it.  Yes, it does have a different feel from the PCs I have had (HP, Toshiba, Acer), but it was a good difference from the first time I put my fingers to the keyboard and began typing.  The screen display is absolutely amazing and totally blows me away.  I absolutely love the programs that come with it; how the Mac itself functions, the appearance and quality of the Mac.  Everything about it is pure joy and I am 100% delighted with my purchase.  As far as the Mac vs. PC debate - by day two I was sold out to Macs.  While I had been use to a 17-inch screen display, the 13.3-inch screen display of this Mac took zero time to get use to ... plenty big enough for work and play purposes (and did I mention the dynamic awesome graphic display???).

The laptop is still new to me and I'm still discovering things about it daily, so give me a little more time with it and I'll come back to update this review, pros as well as any cons I discover.  At the present the only cons are:

1.) having to use the arrow keys to move up and down pages, as the slide on the right side bar (to hold the curser over and move up and down) doesn't stay up when I move the curser to it - but that may be something I am doing wrong, as I'm still learning the intimacies of the Mac. (Case in point ... a day after writing this, I discovered that moving two fingers together up or down on the touch pad will move the page up / down quite nicely.  lol.)

 2.) battery life thus far isn't nearly as long as I thought it would be, based upon video reviews of this model and item description.  Working on documents, etc. battery life is great,.  However, playing the two games I enjoy on Facebook (Criminal Case and CSI) with some surfing the web in between will drain the fully-charged battery down to 20% in just 2 hours.  Playing the games some with more time spent surfing the web, etc. drains the battery from fully charged to 43% in 3 hours.  Will battery life stretch with use?  I don't know.  Would battery life be extended if the games were on the laptop itself instead of online at a web site?  I'm not sure, but think perhaps ...

Let me add, the vender DataVision Computer Video gives exceptional service.  After placing my order for the MacBook Air and discovering that I would be unable to upgrade the RAM, I sent in a cancellation request that was handled by 'Mike S.'  Mike politely cancelled my order no problem, and when I placed an order for this Macbook Pro the very next day, he handled it personally and got it in the mail the same day, even though I didn't request it or pay extra for speedy delivery.  When the Mac arrived it was VERY adequately and securely packaged; I was very pleased. NOTE: hubby and I don't have a a lot of extra money to indulge in extras, after bills and living expenses, so a purchase like this is something really big for us and we try and chose wisely.  Not only am I more delighted with the MacBook Pro than I hoped to be, but hubby is so impressed with it that HE wants to convert from his PC to a Mac, as soon as we can swing it.

JANUARY 21, 2016 UPDATE:  I love this laptop even more than before.  Feel totally comfortable with it, and will never go back to a PC.

JUNE 19, 2016 UPDATE: the love story continues.  This MacBook is such a blessing and I would feel somewhat lost without it.  If you're considering getting this MacBook, proceed with confidence.  It has been super easy to become familiar with it; the more I use it, the more I appreciate it!

PERSONAL MESSAGE
I paid full price for Macbook Pro; I DID NOT get it at a discounted price in exchange for an evaluation.  So, why did I take the time to write a detailed review?  Because I am like you  I depend upon the comments and experiences of other consumers when making an Amazon purchasing decision - especially an important one, such as this.

Even when I do provide a review in exchange for a free or discounted product, I don't feel obliged to write a positive one, just an honest and fair one.  Also, when reviewing products upon request I do not always rate a product 5 stars, or even 4 stars. If in doubt as to my credibility as an unbiased reviewer (whether I pay full price for a product or not), please visit my public profile page and read the personal message in my bio.  Thank you.

I could not live without my MacBook Pro. I have had it for two years and have never had one issue with it. I will never again buy a Microsoft computer. The HDMI hookup is aweseome, the retina display is amazing, and the sturdy feel and construction of the laptop is top of the line. I couldn't come up with a con if I tried.

Stop and read this full review, it will tell you everything you need to know about this computer, good and bad.
I've owned a 15 inch retina since 2012 so I definitely know what I am talking about.

-Boots up quickly from a cold boot to fully functional.
---Takes about 4 seconds to fully boot from a cold starts. It takes about 5 second to rewake when its sleeping (which is weird). If you don't have the charger in, it will go to sleep when you close the lid. If the charger is in, when you close the lid it will just go into standby and immediately resume when you open the lid.

-Screen
---The retina display is one of my favorite thing about this macbook. Its very beautiful. If you try to use a laptop without PPI after using this you will feel anger. The display has some major problems however. Apple has addressed the problem with the clear coat coming off of the screen. This is a huge problem affecting many users. However, they will replace it for free even if your macbook is out of warranty. My freind has had to get his screen replace 3 times! All for free however.

-Battery life
--- When you first get this computer will you will get on average about 7 hours of battery out of this. If you are only surfing or typing up papers then you will get about 9 hours. After the first 2 months, you will start to notice the battery is dying fast and fast each time. After one year, I have notice that I can only get 4 hours out of my laptop before it dies. So after 6 months, bring your charger around with you.

-Opening apps is a breeze, things open up within 2 seconds. Takes to the SSD and PCIE SSD.
---Most apps such as safari, mail, word and other daily applications most people use open up nearly immediately due to some of the software being dump on the ram. If you use a application frequently enough, it will keep the application in the ram and open nearly instantly. In the new OS X, there are a few problems, currently in 10.11, the laptop lags a bit sometimes. It has crashed on my under heavy usage more than 6 times in the last month. Causing em to lose important docs. This shouldn't be a problem in the future and I will update when/if they fix the problem.

-Doesn't run very hot when in your lap.
--- I am able to keep this in my lap and watch videos and stream movies and surf the internet without it getting burning hot. However, more demanding applications will get this laptop hot (70-90 degrees fahrenheit). You can also control the fan speed with 3rd party application easily.

-OS X UI is clean, things are all over the place and things are easy to find.
---Everything is organized and neat. No need to go wandering around all over the place. Your bluetooth and wifi settings are where you think they will be and everything is self explanatory

-Beautiful looks, silver on black is nice. (Gray on black would be better tho)
---The macbook's design hasn't changed much for nearly 10 years. If it's not broken don't fix it. However, if they can add color options to the pro line that would be awesome.

-Multitasking on a mac is very simple.
---I nearly run over 30 tabs all at once with mail open, word, photos, itunes, skype and messages open and I am only using 12 GB of the 16 available. That's good memory management.

- Warranty
---Apple stands by there products and you will have this product under warranty for  a year for free. This will come in handy because you WILL need to get work done of this computer. After the first 8 months, the fans will start making humming noises and the laptop will get hot.

-Trackpad and keyboard
---The trackpad is great for multi gestures. However, it can be better, you will need a mouse if you are doing anything heavy on this computer because of the trackpad setup. The keyboard is one of my favorite and it's very easy to clean and maintain. The typing experience is nearly perfect and key travel is spot on.

-Portably
--- 4.5 pounds doesn't sound like much until it's hanging off your shoulder for an hour. It's not the lightest laptop but it's not the heaviest. But you aren't buying a pro for it's weight.

-Ports
--- It does well with ports, why is there no 3.5 input port? Some users will have to buy a separate device for their needs but they could have fitted that. It does include an SD card port which is nice. 2 USB 3.0 and HDMI 1.0 and two thunderbolt 2.0 ports.

-Facetime camera
--- 720p camera on a 2000 computer is disgusting. But the camera does it's job well. Video chat will be clear. You will always know when the camera is on with the green led that is connected to the camera's voltage input line. Which means it can't be hacked to turn off, it is hardwired to the camera.

-Connections
-- You will definitely get your network's full bandwidth on this computer. It has 802.11 AC and is backwards compatible with other standards. Bluetooth 4.0 does the good perfectly. However, there is sometimes a problem trying to connect bluetooth earphones to this computer. After about 5 times of turning bluetooth on and off it connects, maybe just my earphones.

I can not say enough good things about this 15" MacBook Pro. It is an AMAZING computer. Despite being in IT I have never owned a Mac and considered them sort of an "overpriced cult product". I only bought this because I need to develop an iOS app and X Code is only available for Mac, and I opted for top of the line on the assumption that "Im only going to buy one" so I might as well buy one that lasts for years.  Was I ever wrong! After spending the weekend setting this up and using it, I am going "full Apple" and now plan to replace my desktop with an iMac. I should have made the switch years ago!

First of all. This computer is FAST. Lightning fast. I can't believe how fast. It can't be explained away by the system specs as I have used i7 chips with 16GB of RAM before. I have used SSD drives before, and computers running Windoze are just never this fast, OS X is a FANTASTIC operating system. Incredibly user friendly, and extremely low overhead. I have been deliberately running multiple high resource things and haven't broken 12% on the activity monitor. This has power to spare.  Click an attachment and it opens instantly no spinning, no circling, no thinking about it. Poof its there.

The quality is amazing. The case is aluminum, and there is no detectable noise when the computer is running. It boots in seconds. The display is better than my HDTV. The keyboard has a good feel and backlit keys, the "Force Touch Trackpad" takes a little getting used to because of muscle memory and habits from the HP / Windows world I came from but it is vastly superior and I know I will love it once I unlearn old habits. This is  what a notebook computer should be.

As for transitioning to the Mac environment, I found it both easy and intuitive. I expected to spend all of next week trying to set it up and figure it out, but that was not the case. I was up and running in two evenings, and back to actual productive work on the second evening. If your a casual user it will take you even less time as that included installing several browsers, MAMP, Eclipse IDE, NetBeans IDE, Android Studio, X-Code, Java Development Kit, MySQL Workbench, Joomla, Drupal, and Wordpress installations, multiple printers, a couple of VPNs, multiple email accounts, and a ton of other things that the casual user will not need to do.  The non-IT / non-Developer user probably won't need to install anything and should be up and running within an hour of opening the box.  The apps that come factory installed are great. If you are used to Windows, you are used to new computers being packed full of useless crap, semi-functional watered down versions, and trials. Thats not the case in Mac. Pages, Numbers, and Keynote are in my opinion superior to Word, Excel, and Powerpoint and they will open and save as the MS Office formats if you ned to. (They will also save as PDFs). I would say Pages is actually functionally equivalent to Word and Publisher rolled into one. Its Word Processing and Desktop Publishing functionality combined. The Mail, Contacts, and Calendar apps are in my opinion better than Outlook and far more intuitive to use. Finder is like Windows Explorer / Windows File manager and should be an easy transition. Safari is a great web browser, Maps is super useful, and iMovie, Photos, and Garage Band take care of your multimedia creation and editing needs - though a professional artist or video editor will no doubt want something higher end. But if an ordinary user looking to edit videos for YouTube or home movies, or to edit photos for web pages or blogs, this machine will be off and running out of the box. The Mac lets you work without spending a fortune on a productivity office suite, and buying all kinds of specialty programs.

I have absolutely nothing negative to say about this particular computer, or Mac in general. It was a fast, easy, and smooth transition and the product is physically superior to any Windows computer I have ever used. Apple's attention to detail is amazing right down to the magnetic power cord connector. The battery life is phenomenal - you can work all day. The Retina display is better than a plasma TV. The interface and user experience is  amazingly well thought out and very intuitive. It seems apple spared no detail. They even have your weather, a world clock, a calculator and a calendar on the desktop. (with options for more things like ski reports, stock prices, ski reports etc) The are several gestures on the trackpad that are extremely handy. For example 4 fingers swiped up displays all open windows tiled on the screen. The machine came with OS X Yosemite, and the app store offered a free one click upgrade to OS X El Capitan which took only minutes to do. They also provided a free iBook (like Apples version of Kindle) uses manual.

In the interest of full disclosure - the hard drives in these, while blazing fast, are fairly small by modern standards. HOWEVER, keep in mind that you have iCloud storage, and an external hard drive is quite inexpensive. (I bought a 1TB Western Digital here on Amazon for less than $50 and the machine has plenty of ports including firewire and usb 3.0) With all the developer tools and apps I installed, including a 16G database project Im currently working on, I still have 198 GB free. My advice would be "don't clutter up your drive" with old junk. Use the internal hard drive for your apps and temporary storage of things your currently working on, and then move lesser used stuff and archival copies to iCloud, Dropbox, or some kind of external storage like a flash stick, external drive, or the Apple "Airport Time Capsule" which also does automatic backups. The hard drive size won't be a problem if your not a data hoarder.

In summation - buy this, and never look back. Its an expensive notebook, but its a fantastic notebook with blazing speed and fantastic quality and you will make the money back by increased productivity, reduced aggravation, and saving a fortune on buying software to do things OS X does right out of the box. I'm kicking myself for not having gotten one of these long ago, it would have made my life so much easier.

Apple is going downhill fast.  I have been a a loyal Apple customer for over 10 years.  I have been willing to pay a premium for their products (over twice as much as competitors) because they work, and when they don't they are fixed without hassle.  The latest computers, including these new MBPr plus the minis, are a step backwards.  They combine everything into a single board and solder it together-- MB, RAM, video, everything.  If one thing fails, it must all be replaced (who makes a computer that you can't even upgrade the RAM!?!?!).  And the cost of the repair translates to throwing it away and buying a new computer.

I have a documented, known and recognized by Apple issue with my MBPr.  The video component of the MBPr was shipped defective from Apple from the start.  There is a special Apple repair program to resolve this.  But the issue is intermittent.  It may crash the computer (or show trash on the screen) for two days in a row, and then be fine for weeks.  They will not perform the repair until the intermittent problem appears in their shop.  After two days in their shop, surprise, it does not come up.  They refuse to fix my $2500 computer until THEY see it happen.  They don't trust their customers that the issue is there.  Like we would go through all this trouble for nothing.

I have lost faith in Apple.  Time to delve back into the Windoze world again.  Maybe there is a manufacturer out there that still has decent customer service.  Apple doesn't any more.  And they aren't building them like they used too either.

Better than I expected and I like it so much more than my 13" MacBook Air. It's not as heavy I as I thought it would be and is very fast. I usually buy directly from Apple, but Amazon had such a good price- I couldn't resist. I only buy items like this if it "Ships from and sold by Amazon.com".
It was given as a gift.  The recipient is very, very, very pleased.

First impressions:

  Elegant, solid, beautiful, artistic. There's an X factor to Mac (pun if you'd like) that PC's just don't have. All elements of the laptop, from the OS, to the screen, to the body, keyboard, and fan, like a great symphony, come together to produce the experience so many hail. To compare the Mac to a car, its definitely a Rolls Royce, or Cadillac, or a high end Mercedes; not meant to be pushed too hard or taken cross country, but a driving experience that will make you fall in love with your daily routine once again.

At a glance:

Keyboard is among the best if not the best I've ever used. As aesthetically pleasing as the laptop is, I can't complain about anything ergonomically. The tactile feedback is excellent whether you use a soft or harsh touch. The trackpad is a pleasure to use and I don't miss mouse buttons one bit. Once you get the gestures down, it feels quite natural. All surfaces have a wonderful texture to them. It really is a pleasure working on this machine and I find myself babying it as to prolong its new feel :). Its engineered as it was designed - to perfection. Nothing rattles, creaks slides or bends in this machine. The hinges seat the screen perfectly to the chassis and the action is butter smooth. Overall, this machine is a delicate flower... a far cry from the days of my ThinkPads.

OS:

 Truly a symphony. Goodbye bloatware, popups, awkward designs schemas. Id hate to admit it, but OS X alone could justify the price premium.

Taptic engine:
 Way cool how it simulates a mouse click both physically and acoustically. The gestures are great too.

Chasis:

  Good. The material is light and solid which feels great when the laptop is docked on the desk or other surface, however,  the lack of ductility makes the machine rigid to the point I feel that Im stressing the laptop by picking it up single handedly, which is an annoyance. Also, because of apples narcissistic vanity, the clearance between the screen and the keyboard is nearly 0, so prepare to see smudges from the keys if you put any stress on the lid when its closed (ex. picking it up single handedly, being rugged with the laptop at all when its closed).

Charger: What in the actual f**k is up with this charger. It falls out all the time and seems pretty cheap compared to the rest of the laptop. The wire is prone to crimping which means it will be prone to fraying somewhere down the line. Best re-enforce is with some duct tape or clear packing tape if you're into the whole aesthetic look.

Screen:
 Makes the 1080p on my last high end laptop look like pixelated garbage :). The colors are superb. Retina all the way.

Performance:
 It would be nice to have skylake or even broadwell under the hood for what it retails for (I wouldn't pay retail or even close to it for this setup), 14nm vs 22 nm physical footprint should see about an hour increase in battery life yada yada, but for my purposes no significant difference other than the psychological win. This box uses the 4770HQ for the base model 15, which was put out only last year but is still based on 2013 tech. Again, not a biggie for consumer or moderate level users but probably deters pros since skylake is already being implemented in PCs like the surface pro.

Conclusion:

 If you want the Mac experience but can't see envision yourself using their dwarf sized 13'' laptop then this is the only option. Coming from PCs, I really cant justify the price you pay for the technology you get under the hood, but that seems to be compensated for by apples precision engineering and unparalleled build quality.

I bought a 15-inch MacBook Pro directly from Apple with their AppleDoesn'tCare protection, which does not cover accidental damage. The screen was damaged with very light pressure from a headphone, and, of course, this damage was not covered by the AppleDoesn'tCare warranty. I had purchased the laptop at a time when the Retina display was an upgrade option, and had purchased it with this option. When I asked the first AppleDoesn'tCare representative about the possibility of using a less expensive display for the repair, he insisted that no other displays were compatible with the laptop's configuration. When I asked another AppleDoesn'tCare representative how it was possible that the laptop could support an external display and have a Retina display as one of several options when it was born, yet only be compatible with a Retina display when it needed surgery, he finally admitted that I could have a third part do my repair with a different display, but that Apple was too blunt to allow such variations from the initial specifications. Also, for some reason, Apple could not keep track of the change in my original configuration if a different display were to be used, even if Apple did the repair. Really? Additionally, using a third party would void my AppleDoesn'tCare warranty. How convenient. As I saw that Apple was unwilling to allow any less expensive options, and I had already wasted enough time talking with a company that was too stupid to allow even the simplest variation to a computer as using a different output device (screen), I finally forked over the $1260 (63% of the purchase price or about the cost of 2.5 similar-sized laptops from Hewlett-Packard) that they insisted was the only way Apple new how to replace the screen. Damage repairs make this device almost prohibitive. It is no wonder that BestBuy cannot afford to offer GeekSquad protection for Apple laptops, but instead offers the AppleDoesn'tCare warranty. Take care of your laptop as AppleDoesn'tCare how much they charge to repair it. And now, let us all pray that our MacBook Pro screens do not crack. Ameen! (Amen!).
