So, this is not only a review of this Macbook Pro, but of my experience with MacBooks as a whole.

My first experience with Apple laptops was earlier in 2015 when I had a good bit of spare money & decided to try out a Macbook Air 13".  I was coming off of a very reliable, high resolution PC I'd had for a few years and the Air's screen sort of killed it for me.  I was getting used to the OS X operating system, but all in all I just didn't feel it was worth the $1,000 I'd spent.  So, I returned it and went with another PC.  Fast forward nine months.  I've literally gone through three PC's, all of which had a combination of major and minor flaws.  From utterly terrible trackpads to battery life that were barely over an hour and a half, I realized that modern PC's are being made as cheaply as possible and nobody really seemed to expect them to last more than a year or two.  That's when I remembered how incredibly sturdy the Macs were, and decided to give them another shot.

I decided to fork over the ~$1,300 for a 13" MacBook Pro with retina display and I absolutely love it.  The screen is pristine and clear, the keyboard is phenomenal, the construction is completely solid, and the battery life is phenomenal (I get roughly between 8-10 hours depending on how heavy my workload is, but always running at 100% screen brightness).  On top of that, the single greatest feature is the trackpad.  Scrolling is so unbelievably fluid compared to PC's.  Wherever your finger goes, so too does the indicator, and 2-finger scrolling seems second nature.  Add to that the precision and ease of the 2015's new electronic pressure click, and it's hands down the greatest trackpad available today.

Bottom line, buy this laptop.  You won't regret it.  I'm done with PC's from here on out, and firmly in the Apple camp.

I've had this computer for nearly three years. So far, its logic board has been replaced twice: once because of defective memory and once because of defective video card under the MacBook Pro Repair Extension Program for Video Issues (...). Its top case has been replaced once under warranty because of defective battery. The retina display's anti-reflective coating has been peeling off progressively for the past year. Ultimately, the only original parts of my MacBook Pro still intact are:

 the bottom case (which is just a piece of aluminium);
 the SSD;
 the defective display (see attached pictures).

This review is for the mid-2015 MacBook Pro 15.4 inch retina. 2.5ghz, 16 gigs ram, 512 gigs memory, Intel iris and AMD graphics.

I have owned it for eight weeks now. My review only reflects what I have encountered thus far for my needs.

I got this computer because I am a college student, an Internet abuser, and most importantly, a software developer. This is my first Apple product after the iPad Air which I thoroughly enjoy. I switched from windows because windows 8 was beyond frustrating in so many ways, enough to make me experiment on something new. Folks have been saying for years that Apple machines are designed to create digital media, so I gave in.

The Pros

Speed. The Adobe creative suite runs like a champ. Waiting time is measured in half seconds for even the largest files. I am blown away by this. The programs no longer show any load time.  They just work when you click the icon. Android Studio, Xcode, eclipse. Sometimes the splash screen whizzes by in an instant, even when several editing programs are open at once. I have yet to encounter a loading bar. Going through thousands of photos in the file manager? No loading. There they are.  Very cool. I used to walk around with a half open laptop because once you close windows you can wait forever for it to start up. Not with this thing. I close it and open up right where I left off.

Speaker volume. In the summer heat we keep the air conditioning on which made watching movies on other laptops and the iPad straining on the ears. This machine is loud booming and proud. It is not a boom box but you never want it to be full volume in public.

The keyboard feels amazing. I type fast. Very fast and very hard. I was worried the keyboard would be too soft or be too flat. I assumed it would take a while to get used to a new keyboard. I was wrong. My hands felt like they finally found their home.  The touch pad never, ever accidentally interferes. And it glows and it has a dimmer switch. Nice work Apple.

Graphics. I went to download some first person shooter games to test the AMD card. It was quite unusual to check off max graphics performance settings and will take getting used to. Another thing to note is that the anti-glare screen is quite effective even with a bright lamp behind me. I noticed that what was once a problem on my previous computer is a thing of the past.

Function Keys. No mysteries here. I use them often, to do things such as dim the screen and keyboard, volume control, and open window navigation. It sounds small but the little things count. They are very effective and make sense.

Battery power. It depends on what I am doing, but i get a full 8 hours when I am using it for browsing and development work. This number goes down to 4-6 for watching movies via the browser. It charges relatively quickly. I have gone from zero battery to full charge in about an hour, which is better than my phone!

 I really appreciate the power cable being as long as it is. The extension is permanently attached for me but can be taken off. I question who actually uses just the smaller connector. I also like the feature that has a light turning green when it is fully charged.

The cons.
The Apple App Store kind of sucks. This is understandable given that so many things can be found in the browser. There are noticeably not many games compatible with Macintosh, despite their brand popularity. Steam is very sad to go through. That little windows icon is on everything and the Apple logo on very little.

No side split screen. A feature that all developers use is split screen. Following a guideline or tutorial is much easier when you can dual screen. I really miss this feature from windows.

Mouse compatibility. We have an apple Magic Mouse from 2010 era and the laser on it does not register. It works on older macs but not this one. Kind of annoying and sad. A touchpad will just not do for photoshop and precision gaming controls.

The file system is weird. Is everything stemmed down from the desktop? As a former windows user I am used to seeing the trees. With this, not so much. I worry about cluttering my desktop.

The arm rest is kind of sharp on the edge. This leaves red line marks on my wrist at times. An oversite by engineers?!

My final verdict is this is the most capable, powerful machine I have owned thus far, and I can see why so many people love MacBook.  The attention paid to little details shows a love of design by Apple and the effort they put into their money maker shows. I look forward to putting serious use into this machine for at least five years.

I bought a new one recently. Yesterday when I opened it, I found the retina did not display clearly as I expect a new mac pro should. Really frustrated to see that the new computer did not display as clear as the computer provided by my company, which I have used for more than two months. The difference is really observable.

I still have to pay the shipping fee and 15% restocking fee. I just pay around $200 to get this trouble. So sad.

Got the upgraded CPU(2.8Ghz), 512SSD with AMD discrete graphics model from Apple Store. I as a long time windows user, finally decided to give Mac a try on the frontier of workstation. I was drawn immediately by the appearance of the laptop. The total design gives it a much more premium feel. I know Apple has been using this same design for many years, but why switch if the design still works? I also find it to be pretty thin and light, for a workhorse. I can carry it around quite easily, which is a huge plus for me.

As far as performance, I think I am pretty much getting what I would expect from a workstation: blazing-fast speed, beautiful display, reliable hardware and software. That's the good side.  For the bad side, there is fan noise and heat. Yes, most computers run pretty hot and loud with relatively demanding tasks, and Macbook Pro is no exception. I also want to point out another thing. That's the price. You can very likely get a similar spec PC workstation with lower price than this Macbook Pro. But for Apple, I guess you pay more for the quality of product and service, more reliability, etc. Again, which aspect should be valued more, everyone has their own opinion.

If you take a look at last years model it has a 5 start rating and this one is even better. For 2015 Apple has added a newer SSD thats over double the speed of last years (which was already faster than standard). They swapped out the trackpad for a brand new design called force touch that doesn't actually click but simulates a click with magnets. If you didn't know it you wouldn't be able to tell! It fells just like a click but with the benefit of being quieter and more consistent no matter where you press. It allows you to press harder to get a secondary click for more functions on OS X as well as track sensitivity. Apple already had one of the best trackpads and this is a big jump in quality, hard to go back to the 2014 after using this one.

The last update is the new AMD GPU. This results in support for 5K displays, 1 extra hour of battery life, and from 20% to over 100% improvement in apps like Final Cut X which use OpenCL. The raw power is similar between last years Nvidia GTX 750M (Apple lists 20% improvement). With programs that are still biased towards CUDA the 2014 model is slightly better with the Nvidia card but most software is being updated and OpenCL will be taking over in the near future.

I took a good while and compared this 2015 version to last years model with Nvidia graphics and wrote out a full article as well as YouTube video Testing multiple benchmarking programs as well as 1080P and 4K tests with and without effects. Also included is stabilizer tests as well as test where I have 4x 4k clips scaled into a 4K timeline, each clip has 2 Luts applied and film grain. This is a VERY CPU/GPU intensive test. Theres too much information to pass on here but you can check that out just do a search for Max Yuryev 2014 VS 2015 Macbook Pro and you'll find the video, as well as a link to the full article in the video description. The article also has results from the same tests run on my $5000 MacPro, $3000 5K retina iMac, and $1300 mackintosh for you to compare these MacBooks to.

This is a beautiful laptop. It's lightning fast and half the size of my old Macbook Pro with Handoff compatibility, a slightly faster processor, a studier solid state drive, and gorgeous Retina display to boot. I have to admit that was really, really tempted to get the new Macbook because it's even lighter than this one, by about 1.4 pounds if you want to get specific, and I knew I'd feel the extra 1.4 pounds carrying it around on campus. I eventually decided on the Pro, mainly because the 1.3 GHz processor on the regular Macbook was a huge step down from my old Mac Pro and I thought it would bother me to have a slower processor, but also for a host of other reasons.

First off, price. Since I was already getting a 512 GB memory to fit all my music and photos, it was actually only a $100 difference to get the Pro. More importantly, in the end, it would have actually been the same price since Apple charges $80 for the Macbook adaptors. See, there's one port on the new Macbook for power and everything else, so you'd need an adaptor to plug in, say, headphones or a USB cable. Apple insists that this is the way of the future and everything can be done wirelessly, but honestly? I'm not there yet. The Pro, on the other hand, has two USB ports, an SD card port, an HDMI port, two lightning ports, and a headphone port in addition to the power supply port. Apple has taken out the disk drive since my 2011 model to make the computer thinner and lighter, but if you really need one, you can get an external lightning-connected one. Honestly, I never used mine, and I prefer the lighter weight of the new Pro over having a disk drive I thought I might use but never did, since now it's actually feasible to take this powerful laptop to class or a caf without having a freaking brick in my backpack.

Let's talk personal use, though. That's the big thing to consider when buying a computer-- what you'll be using it for. As a college student, I sometimes run web-based Virtual Machines on my computer because Macs don't have ArcGIS, a map program I use in my classes and research. This was a big factor in deciding to get the Pro instead of the slower (but lighter) new Macbook. When I got home and tested out the VM on my new Pro, it laughed at my silly test. I could switch between the VM and other Mac apps seamlessly, and even running ArcGIS didn't seem to slow down my computer. That's a huge, bulky program, so it's pretty incredible to have that kind of power. My mom went with the Pro for the same reason; she's a doctor and used a VM of sorts before I'd even heard of them; she has a remote connection to her Windows desktop at work so she can access her digital ultrasound images when she's at home. My sister, on the other hand, mainly uses her computer for browsing and watching videos and writing an essay for school every so often, so she has a Macbook Air and would likely be a new Macbook type of user if she were currently in the market for a new computer. Basically, if you use your computer for VM's, Photoshop, video and music editing, or anything other than just basic browsing, video-watching, and document editing, you will appreciate having the more powerful Pro. Even if you do just use it for essay-writing, having 15 tabs of sources open on Safari plus your current draft open on Word will be a breeze with the Pro. I haven't even seen the Mac beach ball in the two months since buying this computer. For gaming, though, you'll want the 15-inch Pro because it has a dedicated graphics card... unless you want to run all your games at the lowest possible graphics settings and frame rates.

Honestly, the decision of what computer to buy is based on your personal needs, preferences, and budget. But let me assure you, this is an amazing computer. It's lighter and thinner than any other Macbook Pro without sacrificing any of the computing power that comes with the Pro line. The battery life is more than enough to last me all day in classes. It's incredibly fast and makes running big programs look easy. And I have to gush about the Retina display. It is amazing. I'm really not one to go gaga over the newest high-definition thing, but compared to my 2011 Macbook, the display is so crisp and sharp and colorful. Technically speaking, the only difference between Retina and the older screens is sharpness because of the higher pixel count, but it makes a huge visual difference in image quality. I can't speak for durability and long-term use just yet as I've had it less than two months, but I will update later on that topic. As of right now, though, I am very happy with my decision to get the powerful Pro over the shiny new Macbook.

I bought the 256GB/16GB RAM, IRIS PRO only option. The machine is clearly overpriced compared to Windows machines of similar configuration that come with additional GPUs. However, those machines don't come with OS X, the terrific build quality, the great keyboard, the unmatched trackpad, and the unbeatable apple support.

PROS:
Trackpad - is unmatched in the windows world
Trackpad gestures - make using the machine very intuitive and increases your productivity
Keyboard - one of the best, only surpassed by thinkpad machines
Screen - retina screen is gorgeous, crisp, detailed and great for photo editing and movie watching
OS X - fast, reliable, virus free operating system that is YEARS ahead of windows in stability, support, function.
SSD speed - the SSDs on these machines have the fastest speeds of any current machine offered
Sound Quality - via the speakers is decent
Sound Quality - via the headphone jack is phenomenal and quite possibly one of the best in the industry. Will drive any high headphones without trouble, producing crispy highs, clear and forward miss, and low notes. Volume output is also one of the best in the industry. This is a given for a company as invested in the music industry as apple is.

CONS
- Expensive compared to other brands with similar or better specs (not for SSD)
- you cannot install WINDOWS 7 if you need it (as I do) via bootcamp, only WINDOWS 8
- no ability to upgrade SSD space only in the IRIS PRO version (unless maybe you custom order via APPLE directly)
- I wish the screen was a little brighter

I suffered with Microsoft for 20 years, but the apple computers we had in college never impressed me either. They were clunky and crashed as often as windows. Windows 7 gave false hope that Windows may be ironing its problems finally but Windows 8 and later 8.1 and 8.2 shattered all my hopes and I decided after 20 years of suffering, enough is enough. I decided to try and see what apple is all about. The ride pricing, the low specs, the fact that only unsay people around me seemed to use apple was always a deterrent. I decided to bit the bullet:

1. Call apple to buy a mac, I was put on home for 5 minutes before I could talk to anyone. BAD SIGN right there. You are trying to cough up good cash to a company and they are not even giving you a good initial impression?

2. The sales person had little training and was unable to answer any of my concerns about apple's puny specs and high prices. Instead of defending Apples alleged advantages, he says so did you want to go ahead with the order?

3. A day after the order, I remembered from years ago that you can get MacBooks from amazon about 10% cheaper. So I called them and asked if they would extend that as a courtesy. They said I should have asked when ordering. I asked to talk to a manager. They said sure, hold on! They kept coming back to me every 2 minutes and saying please wait. I waited 40 minutes to talk to a manager. Id di all this to test their crappy system. The manager said the same thing and asked that I order from amazon and by the time I was done, I had been on the phone for 50 minutes. BAD SIGN!

4. I said screw it I am ordering from amazon. I got a return authorization and ordered from amazon. Amazon laptop showed up 5 days later. By then, I had played with the 1st laptop a little to test it and learn appleze way of doing things. It was not as intuitive as usually claimed. 

5. I tried the apple migration tool to migrate the files I had created on the first macbook. I had basically loaded up 10 gigs of photos to the first macbook and favorited them and done some editing. I wanted to test the migration tool that touted to make your life so much easier; one of the reasons I wanted to switch to a mac. i did not want to trash a laptop every 2 years and set up a new one like I had done for years with Windows.

6. The migration thru wifi sucked as it went thru for a few hours and froze. It did not go any further for half a day. I called them later and had to wait a while each time and overtime I would ask them to call me back in half an hour, instead of the tech calling me again, i would get a robot call, had to punch in numbers and wait 5 minutes to talk to a completely different person.

7. The techs would claim the previous tech was maybe out to lunch or such, but this happened a 3rd time. When I complained to the 3rd tech why I don't get call back from the 1st tech, she (Ebony) hung up.

8. The tech support took 2 hours of my time to basically convey a simple message of holding control-R after rebooting and trying again. The migration had started with the 2nd tech person, but was showing 43 hours to complete!!! They said that is normal and maybe cable usage in your area is too high right now.

9. So the migration from laptop to another sitting next to it was going thru the local internet traffic and I was not going to dash out and buy a thunderbolt cable as I was not sure I like Apple by that point. Their local store is also a zoo and their tech support had proven to be no oversees but poorly trained Americans on $10/hr.

10. The migration indeed took 50 hours and it finally failed!!! I videotaped my saga over two days to document this. At the end, it said, migration complete, wait a minute. Overall, this is an excellent machine. Good Durability, outstanding performance and portability. No high quality laptop can be made with plastic. The full aluminum frame does an excellent job of protecting the structural integrity of this machine. No other laptop except Razer branded laptops are made of this material. Others may have a aluminum exterior but plastic interiors which warp under heat and degrade over a period of 1 year of use.

Nothing beats the quality of the Mac OS X as well, which is one of the main reasons for this purchase.

This machine tops all other laptops as far as performance with the exception of the bulky, heavy, plastic, burning hot gaming laptops with dual 980m's.
bill gates laptop.

THE GOOD

* Excellent form factor, extremely portable while remaining a serious pro computer
* Incredible display
* Good keyboard
* Decent selection of ports for its size
* Very good battery life

THE BAD

* Very weak WiFi reception from the built-in antenna. If you're a couple dozen feet from the transmitter you're good. If you are farther than that, and maybe have a wall or two in the way, it starts to suck badly. You'll need to get an external antenna for better range.

* Extremely weak graphics card. The Intel Iris SUCKS. The machine is near-unusable out of the box. It stutters and pauses as you switch windows or use the "Show all windows" or "show desktop" functions. You have to "increase contrast" and "reduce transparency" in the accessibility options to make it perform OK, but with a UI that looks like s***.

* You have no option to upgrade to a better graphics card. Apple thinks that if you use a 13" laptop, there's no way you can be a professional in need of a high-performance machine. Paradoxically, this laptop is a "Pro".

* This laptop is MUCH SLOWER than my 2011 Macbook Pro 15". It is incredible that you can "upgrade" your laptop after 5 years and the new laptop vastly underperforms the one 5 years ago. This would be Utterly Unthinkable 10 years ago.

Sadly, Apple is moving into fashion -- your laptop is no longer a performing athlete. Instead, it is a super-thin heroin addicted high-fashion supermodel. Next time you can expect it to be Thinner and More Gold, not higher performing.
Its an Apple so everything works perfectly and it looks beautiful!

I recently had a very poor experience at an Apple store that has left me dumbfounded.

I was having issues with Bluetooth on my MacBook Pro Retina. I spoke with support a few times and they were unsuccessful in debugging the issue. I then swapped my Bluetooth peripherals to another MacBook, tested them and determined the problems were isolated to the MacBook Pro Retina. Since I wanted to confirm the issues were indeed related to the Wi-Fi and Bluetooth module I swapped the Wi-FI Bluetooth module from another unit we had in office and determined the issues followed the module. I openly explained my troubleshooting and debugging process to the Apple Store Genius and was met with ridiculous comments and accusations. I even told them that I used electrostatic discharge protection gloves and grounding before completing the swap but this meant nothing to them.

I calmly tried to explain that by me swapping units to determine if one was faulty does not in fact void my warranty but the Genius technician and his manager both held firm that customers were not to open their laptops and opening a laptop and swapping parts voids your Apple warranty unless a Genius themselves does the install.. I even mentioned the Magnuson-Moss Warranty Act of 1975 and also pointed them to the following legal article, https://www.apple.com/legal/warranty/products/embedded-mac-warranty-us.html  but they had no idea regarding any of this and didn't seem to care.

I was charged for the Bluetooth replacement, while under AppleCare warranty which does not expire until September 5, 2016. I can tell you firmly that this experience has left my confidence in Apple shaken. I was the main contributor at my company who pushed for us to start allowing Apple laptops into the Enterprise. Apple has always been there for me when I have had issues with other devices, but it seems my luck has ended.
XD

This laptop has exceeded my expectations. I needed a portable solution for working in Adobe programs and decided to just buy the most updated model despite the 2013 and 2014 having incredible reviews. The main difference from this model to last years is the new trackpad. I purchased this without any real opinion on the trackpad but now I can't imagine using a Macbook without it. The trackpad is extremely sensitive and I can have an easy click ANYWHERE on the pad. I have less straining in my hands when I am working quickly now. I still use a Macbook Air (2013) and find it slow/cumbersome pushing harder in corners or trying to drag objects with the trackpad.

The computer itself is fast and quiet. The 15" is a perfect size for screen splitting or multi-tasking and have had no issues with lagging. I tend to drain the battery quickly though. I think the battery life isn't significantly better than past models and that is the only disappointing feature I've seen from heavy use. The battery may be better spec-wise....but from daily/normal use I find it average. I plug-in just as often as I did with my older products.

If you are in the Apple world you expect the best. My first Apple (MBP 15 2010), is a faithful companion of many battles; I love it. Unfortunately, I did not investigated enough to find out on time the change program for an issue in the Video Card. The replacement costs about 600 so I decided to buy a brand new, stylish, d** good looking new MBP with a super retina display. Everything in the laptop works fine: lighter, nice and crisp image, optical audio output, speedy USBs... but if you are a fanatic of the high resolution, you will be disappointed. Apple very diplomatically states on the resolution adjustment: "Using a scaled resolution may affect performance". May affect?? If you have a super-hyper-mega brand new Apple MacBook PRO, you would expect to be able to use everything of you laptop to the limit (the over price is not about buying more quality and performance?), the performance of the laptop is very notoriously affected with the resolution change: it just turns slow in many video transitions, new windows, even the writing.

So, retina display is very good looking screen with more than Full HD resolution, but with this laptop, scaling to my 5 years old laptop desktop resolution (1680x1050), turns this laptop into a turtle. Youtube video, lagging, slow window transitions, slow writing, delayed clicking, will be some of the different behaviors you will be face using higher-res scaling display resolution. Therefore, I have to settle with seeing big font windows (1280x800) and Full HD youtube videos, if I want no very notorious performance penalties.

The funny part of this story is that with all the excitement I bought a 4K screen to see the superb resolution of the laptop was capable of.  I have to say that the laptop was able to use the full res of the screen at 60MHz using the thunderbolt port, but IMHO it is too slow for a high end laptop, and even slower for any Apple demanding customer .

I've always been a PC person and I was the first person to jump to defense of PC's when in the "PC versus Mac debate". I said all of this stuff despite never spending a lot of time around Macs. It wasn't until this past year when I was teaching at my school that I was given the Macbook Air 11 inch the first semester and then a 13 inch the second semester. It took me a while to get adjusted, but slowly I started to fall in love with the operating system. I noticed that I didn't have to do simple things such as virus scans, etc. At the end of the year I had to give my computer back and I went back to my PC. It wasn't that my PC was bad, it wasn't able to handle my software needs (Adobe Creative Suite). It was at that moment that I decided to take the Macbook plunge and buy my own. I felt like I had some time to make an informed decision since I spent most of the year working on a Macbook, but I decided for a little more power. Let me tel you this, I'm beyond impressed with this computer. While the Macbook Pro Retina weighs more than the smaller Airs, the weight isn't that big of a deal. I'm able to work with a very powerful program with no problems. Plus the picture on this computer is BEAUTIFUL!!!!

Also, I know people like to make a big deal about the price when it comes to Macbooks. If you actually compare Macbooks with PC's with similar parts there isn't that much of a difference. And here's a helpful hint.... Apple has a pretty generous education discount that they offer to both educators and students of any age. You have to just provide an ID for either yourself or your child.

It's a MacBook, what else do I need to say? Slim, very fast, great screen, lightweight, solid state drives, great battery(even though it burns the battery life when I play my flight simulator due to processing demands of the graphics!)  it's a great computer. The 15" version was just too big for me, this was the perfect compromise. 512gb HD was the perfect choice. If you have the option, get the 16gb of RAM, I only got 8.  While 8 is perfect for just about everyone, the added RAM is a great feature that keeps you running those high graphic apps. Force touch trackpad, pretty freakin awesome. Really does trick your mind since it's not moving! Get one and make the change from PC finally. My MacBook has a KUZY keyboard and shell cover on it in the photos FYI...

I have been thinking about replacing my 2011 macbook air for quite a long time now. Initially it was very slow on Yosemite but I found variety of tweaks to make the Macbook Air actually very effective with Yosemite. The Air is a fantastic computer and even today I think it offers a great array of services. Why did I want to upgrade then? I'm bitten by the Apple bug plus I like to watch films on my laptop (even though I have a projector and a tv)

So I thought about it and thought about it and then finally decided to go to a retailer who was offering it for 99k and purchased the 256GB variant. free space is about 230GB so that means Yosemite is definitely consuming more space. With my Macbook Air, I was always deleting various films after watching them just so I can download more so I went the safe route, have spent more money and got this variant.

Is it seriously fast? Yes, boot times is low, files open just the same as my macbook air, I am not seeing a substantial jump from that point but I think such changes require longer times to fathom. There are some youtube videos which look remarkable, the speakers are much louder but they're not loud enough to replace my external bluetooth speaker. But still I am impressed. Could the speakers have been better? Sure. Are they loud enough to watch a video? Sure.

The keyboard like all "macbook" keyboards is pretty good. It is not very different from the Air but the place your palms rest when you type is more solid and more comfortable at the same time. The trackpad is fun, it does a bunch of fancy things but "Force Touch" remains largely at entry stage. Do you feel an electronic vibration? Hell no. I first thought there is something wrong with my model but researching told me this is just how it works. Well, it is pretty solid.

The battery life is about 8 hours equalling with my iPad Air (Almost) and this is a very important thing. People always told me I can attach an external charger and keep it plugged in. However, I don't do this. I only attach the charger when battery is in the red, I disconnect it when it goes GREEN. Years of computing has taught me this. This also helps longevity of battery. So make sure you monitor battery health closely. It feels wonderful to know I can go somewhere for the day without even carrying a charger.

Features I like -
a) Screen is brilliant. Whether on youtube or surfing, whether I am watching a video. It is not as bright as the macbook air but when I compare it with my macbook air, I can't help but feel the Macbook Air has apology in keeping up with videos whereas Retina is just crisp, beautiful, more vibrant than anything I have seen. Except maybe my iPhone.
b) Speakers are loud and adequate.
c) So far it doesn't make fan noise, it doesn't heat up as much as my Macbook Air did. My Macbook Air would start whiriring when uTorrent would play with battery power.
d) The Force Touchpad is very good. The screen borders are black accentuating the effect of the screen. That is a great idea. There's a reason 99% TV's have black bezel.
e) The mechanism to open the laptop is unique and very finely paved. Also it has a HDMI port without the need for an external accessory. I did try this once and will try it more and add feed back later.

THINGS I DISLIKE -
The charger that accompanies this computer seems very very easy to break. Beware.
Apple has included things like "Keynote" , "Pages" , "Numbers" , etc. Who needs all this? I don't, brother and If I did I should be allowed to add it.
The Micro Fiber cloth included to wipe the macbook will last you exactly 2 days.
512GB model costs so much more. Apple is really mean.
Why is this not 20% brighter? I know I said I like the way the screen looks but the fact that the Macbook Air is brighter is kind of troubling. Supposing i'm out in the sun, the brighter computer will definitely be easier to view. Ever noticed how your phone goes max brightness when you're out in the sun...
I really think the Macbook Air keyboard was 15% easier to type on. The keys depressed significantly better.

Some people are concerned about the Macbook Retina being heavier. Yes, it i substantially heavier but it is good weight. The construction feels very fine. I have muscles so I think I'll be ok. Does the weight make it difficult to carry? NOT REALLY.

Why invest in Retina over Air? The screen and future proofing.
Looking for value for money? AIR
Looking for no apologies? MBP Retina.

To conclude, this machine is really good looking and really effective. It does everything very well, including multimedia, web browsing, video viewing. I am not the guy who's going to edit a bunch of videos or anything but I love this machine. I think even for daily tasking this is a very strong machine. I don't like how people assume only professionals need to get one. I wish Apple would tell me what to do with these useless Thunderbolt ports. I have never used them in my life and don't think I will.

Just a background about myself: I owned the early 2008 15" MacBook Pro, and late 2011 15" MacBook Pro. I am a former engineer and now a finance manager. I play videogames, used for programming (C++, Matlab, R, SQlL, etc.) and did normal productivity tasks. I also record music with Fender/Gibson guitars.

The changes from the 2011 15" MacBook Pro:

Pros
- New ports that were not in the 2011 model: HDMI port, extra Thunderbolt video port (now it has two instead of one)
- New Radeon graphics card (FINALLY!). I had the chance to test the new Radeon graphics card and it's really good.
- Retina display is actually sharper. I thought that it wouldn't make any difference, but it DOES on games
- The computer is 1 pound (approx. 500g) lighter. This is a huge plus!
- Drives are now Solid State Drive. That is awesome. Super fast boot.
- (update!) When the computer is working hard, it doesn't burn my lap anymore (although I do feel some hot air flowing through my fingertips, when I am typing, but I am okay with that).

Cons
- (update!) The new magsafe 2 power adapter is worse than the previous generation. The plug keeps unplugging. I think Magsafe 1 had an optimal grip: if you stepped on the cord, and pulled with enough power to drag the computer, the plug would disconnect. However, for gentle pulls, it didn't disconnect. With Magsafe 2, even the gentlest pull makes the plug to disconnect, which is very annoying for me.
- New built-in speakers. They look the same compared to the 2011 model, but they are slightly worse. The drums in rock songs look very artificial.
- Memory is not easily upgradable anymore. WHY THIS, APPLE? SERIOUSLY?
- SSD (Solid State Drive) is not easily upgradable. See my comment above
- No ethernet connection and firewire 800 port. Honestly, I think nobody uses these ports anyway.
- No AUDIO IN port. Now audio in and out are combined in just one port... I don't like this.
- No DVD drive. A separate device from apple is $70. It's very expensive for such a simple device. There are similar models from $20 to $40.
- The screen is harder to clean. Maybe that's a consequence of how the retina display is built, but yeah, it's harder to keep the screen clean.

Neutral:
- Keyboard keys have a shorter touch. I'm okay with that given that the body is thinner.
- Touch feedback trackpad. In the beginning I felt a little weird about this trackpad. I couldn't drag-and-drop items in it, but after I changed the behavior in settings, everything went well from there. I honestly didn't think it changed much from my regular trackpad on the 2011 model.

Overall, I think it is a great purchase.

This is the first Mac (computer) that I have owned. The new pro model is very light and compact, and can easily be carried around with you every day. The display is amazing and the new force click trackpad is an awesome addition. It's a little weird at first, knowing that the button isn't actually moving when you click down, but you definitely get used to it.

The Mac Pro is also very fast, and I have only experienced the rainbow wheel once or twice whenever I was on a website that wasn't responding.

The only issue I have with it (and hence the four star rating) is the battery life. Although I read countless reviews that said it had above average battery life, I don't seem to be getting that. Playing simple 2D games for 30-45 minutes would kill the battery almost 30%, even with the backlight keyboard off and screen dimmed. Playing Star Wars KOTOR was worse. I blew through almost 80% of a full battery on just over an hour of gameplay (playing a 12 year old game!). The only time I seem to get more than 10 hours is if it's on standby or if I'm just browsing the web and listening to music.

Battery issues aside, I really love this laptop and it is easily the nicest piece of electronics I have ever owned.

I just picked this laptop up last week and all I have to say is WOW. This thing is really fast. Prior to this macabook I had a mid 2009 macbook pro that after a few years I had even upgraded to ssd after a few years, which did give it some decent speed for being 6 years old. This laptop has one of the latest flash ssd drives you can get in it. It can write data at around 1300 mbps and read at 1800 mbps! If you compare that to a traditional 7200 rpm hard drive that might read and write around 100 mbps. So this computer opens files and apps almost immediately. I ran a few tests with it and it will start from a shut down to the login in screen in just a tick under 7 seconds.  So if you don't like waiting this is definitely a great choice of laptop for you. Also,the new track pad is really nice, it does take a little bit getting used to, since I am personally used to the original track pad. This trackpad doesn't have the long downward click like the original but it works very well and the pressure sensitive touching is something that might take more time for more programs to implement its full potential. So if you don't like waiting this is definitely a great choice of laptop for you The only real couple of minor downfalls on this laptop I would knock on it for is probably the size of the ssd, at only 256 gb you can't store a whole lot on that. But I personally use time machine over my home wifi which makes up for it for me. And the other thing is just some of the hardware they're using in the laptop is a couple years old. 16gb of ram is great. But by todays standards 16gb at only 1600 mhz is on the slow side by todays standards. But it is more than adequate. And also the 2.2 i7 broadwell processor is at least a couple years old now. But to Apple's defense. The newest version of the i7 hasn't come out yet. But if you're looking for the latest apple laptop to upgrade to, you will not be disappointed!

If you're here looking at the computer then I'll assume you're already looking at Mac Laptops - which was my case after seeing the new Macbook and its razor thin profile. I needed the computer to act as my main device outside of work, and having the limited processor from the slimmer brethren would not have allowed me to run the computer in the same incredibly multi-task oriented way I typically do.

What matters:
1. This newest version is materially faster than its predecessors - and it isn't just noticeable in the benchmarks.
2. I've yet to find a more powerful, thoughtfully designed, and lightweight computer that can handle my day cradle to grave.
3. If you're coming from a PC you'll love the battery. If you're coming from another Mac laptop you'll either be satisfied or pleasantly surprised.
4. After a couple weeks of use on the new 'taptic feedback' trackpad I would hate to have to lose it. It did take some time to get used to it, though now when I use my colleagues Macbook Air the standard 'diving board' trackpad click feels like I need a hammer to make it register my click. Less of a fault of the much lauded diving board and more a factor of the very well designed new hardware. Again - it DOES take some getting used to, though I've yet to have any desire to move back to older hardware.

I ran with the 128 because I'm fully capable of managing a small local disk with an enormous cloud drive. If you aren't able to understand uploading media then pay more for a larger SSD.

Personal thought from experience for managing small local storage when photos and music are your biggest space abusers:
1- iTunes Match ($25/yr I believe) keeps all of your music synced across all of your iOS devices with no limit. I've found it to be amazing and well worth the cost over the past few years.
2- Amazon Prime Cloud Drive - Free UNLIMITED storage of photos. There's a limit on other stuff (something like 20GB I think) but the auto upload and unlimited photo storage makes my local storage need about 15GB lighter. There's obviously a cost to get Amazon Prime, though if you are alive, use products, live in a place with an address, aren't in jail: why don't you have Prime?

Last note - I'm incredibly anal about ensuring my very heavily used devices still stay looking like brand new. As such, the first thing I bought was a full body clear skin (www.bestskinsever.com - will shout their glory over InvisibleShield until the day I die) which I installed to perfect results. I've noticed that the build tolerances are so tight on this computer that the edges of the 'inside the clamshell' skin can make small marks on the screen showing where it lines up when closed. A testament to both Apple for really making an engineering marvel and to the effects of the use of such a skin.

I have been sorely disappointed with my 2014 13" macBook with retina display. This laptop as a several deeply flawed design issues which have led to 3 replacements of the display, twice costing me $460 each. The magsafe2, the magnetic charging plug is a complete failure in that it disconnects much too easily (unlike the original magsafe). Second the retina display glass is very thin and very fragile. The combination of these design flows leads to broken displays when the magsafe plug is caught inside the computer upon closing, breaking the monitor.

Replaced mid 2012 15" MacBook Pro with 1.3 MHz model.  It is incredibly light, fast, and with all day battery life.  I use office, mail, Lightroom, all are faster than on Pro.  Don't believe the so called "expert" reviews.  As others have pointed out, they didn't get the iPad or the iPhone either.

I ordered this straight from Apple, since I spec'd it out with 16GB ram and 1TB hard drive.  I intended to replace my 2013 Macbook Air, which I love, except for the non-Retina screen.  I had read every review I could find and have read only positive reviews.  I am perplexed as to how anyone using this laptop for more than 10 minutes would miss the issues that were glaring for me.

The sound from the speakers is atrocious.  The maximum volume is low and requires strain to hear.  It is at about 70% the maximum level of my Macbook Air speakers.  This is compounded by the issue that it appears the sound is coming out from the bottom of the machine.  On the Macbook Air, the sound was rising through the keyboard, not coming down out of the chassis and being muffled.

In addition, sound from the speakers creates excessive vibration where vibration is uncomfortably noticeable when the laptop is being used on my lap.  This is especially noticeable to me because this issue does not exist on my Air.

I suppose that most people are happy with this machine and in particular don't notice the sound issues, because just about every laptop has terrible sound from the speakers and expectations are low.  However, sound from the Air is outstanding, and I am from a vantage point of seeing a drastic difference.

Also, I tend to use laptops lying on the sofa with the laptop on my stomach, and this thing is a brick.  I could go the whole day working comfortably with the Air, but I feel this thing on me in every moment.  Yes, I know, per the specs, the Pro seems marginally heavier at half a pound difference.  However, the end perception is not marginal, whether it is the absolute weight difference or the weight distribution difference due to the different shapes of the machines, the Pro is uncomfortable to have sitting on me while the Air was not.

It is absurd that in 2015 Apple can't make a single laptop that is not a brick, with a good screen, with more than one port, and with a processor with post-2011 performance.

Even though I did not purchase my Macbook here at Amazon, (I bought mine refurbished from Apple), I wanted to put my two cents in. I bought the original Mac back in the 80's when they first hit the market, and was very impressed with it, but in those days, there was virtually no software to use with it, and I eventually slipped into the Windows world, but never forgot the smoothness of the old Mac even in B/W.

Finally, because I wanted to use Garageband for making backing tracks for my band, I decided to give up my high end laptop PC, and get this Retina Macbook with 256G SSD and 8G memory. I still have 3 Windows PC's as well as three iPads, an iPhone 6, and my new Apple Watch.  I immediately found the Mac offered a simpler way of computing with no, often confusing, installation procedures nor even more frustrating uninstallation steps. Somehow, there as a sense of tranquility and peacefulness in the air. Holy crap! I almost started singing Kumbaya! Well, not really, but it did feel smooth, and the Retina was visually very pleasing. After a few months, however, I have found that the Mac is not completely perfect, though. I find I have just as many program lockups as I had in Windows 7. Very rare, but it does happen. My biggest disappointment is the Macs memory handling. Most apps, most notably Garageband, just keeps getting slower and slower as I use the app, until I have to save my work then reload to app. I enquired with support from another app I use, Audacity, about the slowness, and they admitted that the Mac is a very poor at memory management. Another disappointment is the Mac Finder. This is the Apple equivalent to Windows Explorer. I miss Explorer. It is far superior to Finder. But that's not much to complain about, is it?  That being said, I'd take the Macbook any day, but Windows isn't as bad as what I was starting to think.

PS 5/6/15 I forgot to mention the 256G storage. Pretty slim to my liking, so I bought a 1T portable USB HDD and velcro'd it to the lid. Works great, but if you do this... you just might be a redneck.

I upgraded form a mid-2011 MacBook Air and love this new Retina Macbook Pro.  The Air is light and extremely portable, but the Pro has the ports that I need.  This is a fast laptop with a GREAT screen.  When I look at the screen on my old MBA (which I liked A LOT), the clarity of the Retina becomes very obvious.  The Touchpad on the 2015 Pro is excellent.  Its response, and ForceTouch work very well.  I look forward to seeing what developers do with this new technology.  The Pro is, of course, heavier than the MBA, but the footprint is just a little smaller. The main selling point for me was the additional power and all of the ports, including an HDMI port which I use a lot for business presentations.  With the MBA, I had to carry an extra adapter.

The 2015 MBPr runs at a decent temperature.  It gets warm, but not quite as "hot" as my MBA used to get.  Battery life for me has been a little less than expected.  I can get about 6 hours of battery life with the brightness at about 75% and doing web searches, Excel/Word work, Powerpoint work, streaming music on and off, and watching a couple videos on news sites.

My most resource intensive applications (Final Cut Pro, Lightroom, and Photoshop) are very smooth on this laptop.  The fan will hit full speed once in a while, but the workflow does not stutter or pause.

An excellent, well-built laptop with a beautiful screen.

Bought this to replace a 2010 MBP. What an awesome laptop! Fantastic build quality, beautiful screen, amazing viewing angles, fast as lightning, silent as a tomb. I have yet to hear the fan start up or feel any real heat from the bottom. It's has enough ports to do whatever I need, I like that the USB's are on opposite sides, as most ports (including the old MBP) are too close together for some clunky thumb drives or cables. The sound is amazing now that Apple moved the ports to the bottom of the laptop. The force touch trackpad is brilliant. It takes a little getting used to but has loads of potential once the applications start utilizing it. I use an older MacBook at work so we'll see how this goes using both. The battery is incredible. I skip carrying my adapter unless I leave town for a couple days. 10 hours easy of average use.

Yes, Macs are expensive up front, however, the joy of using such well-engineered, well-built laptops is worth the price. I have to replace my laptop much less often, don't have to fuss with Windows, anti-virus, anti-malware, drivers, constant security update installations/reboots, Metro-tile interface madness, touch screens, styluses (a crutch since no Windows laptop can match the usability or gestures of an Apple trackpad, especially this new force touch model), or dragging around a typical giant, clunky PC laptop power adapter/cord combo with the thick rubber strap to hold it all together.

Of course, you can run Windows on it via BootCamp (free, Google it) or Parallels software, about $70 on Amazon if you have to run Windows programs. This Mac has plenty of speed and memory to run Parallels like butta'.

If you can afford it, this is the way to go. No PC can touch the Mac experience. Over the long run, they are closer in price then they appear. There's a reason most PC laptops try to look like MacBooks, but ultimately fall well short of a Mac.
Nice

After a bit of internal debate between this and the Macbook Air, I decided to get the Retina Macbook Pro.  What a great decision this was.  I come from using the original late 2008 aluminum Macbook.

Dimensions/Weight:
This Macbook Pro is much thinner and a couple centimeters shorter than my old Macbook.  With how slim this thing is I really don't see a need for the Macbook Air line.  It is pretty light if you are coming from any other laptop except a Macbook Air.

Display:
The display is fantastic on this laptop.  Very sharp screen and good viewing angles.  Something about OS X running with a high resolution display just looks classy in a way that a Windows computer could never match.

Battery life:  I haven't had the laptop for too long but easily get 8 hours or more on a charge.  No complaints here.

Keyboard and Trackpad:
The keyboard is ok.  It is not my favorite, in fact my late 2008 aluminum Macbook has a better keyboard.  Just the way the keys feel when they press in, they are a bit softer on this model compared to my old one and I prefer a bit harder feel when typing.  It's all a personal preference.  Other than that, the key sizes are good and the backlighting works just fine.

The trackpad has gotten better with this new model.  The click is now provided by a haptic engine and provides more functionality.  The thing is fantastic.  The trackpad still does move a tiny bit, but it isn't a big movement like the older type.  This is easily the best trackpad I have ever used.

Speed:
This computer is blazing fast.  Apps open instantly and the AC wifi performance is very nice.

OS:
With OS X Yosemite, the OS is very refined and elegant.  You can even run time machine backups while the computer is sleeping now.  I'm not sure when this feature was introduced, but it is very welcome.  The OS is easy to use, the app store lacks many apps that I use, so I have to go directly to the developers site to download them.  I have not messed with the continuity feature much, but it is nice having the favorites and open tabs sync from my laptop to my iPhone.

Overall:
In my opinion, having used a Surface Pro 3, older MacBooks and many other computers over the years, this is the closest to perfect I have ever seen a computer get.  If I were to improve anything it would be to switch to the 2008 macbook style keyboard with the "harder" feel to the keypress and I would also add a third USB port.  The current model only has two, which can be problematic if you hook up an external hard drive and an external bluray drive (which requires two ports) at the same time.  You need a USB hub to help you in that situation.
I bought this Macbook  for my daughter. She is absolutely in love with it. She had came from a Dell computer and she has told me there is no comparison.  So far, I would have to say A+.

What an impressive machine this is. Beautiful, functional and has worked so far without a single glitch. It is powerful, fast and attractive. The screen holds its own among high resolution notebook screens. The price represents a decent discount for a device that normally sells at the MSRP. The item came quickly, was well packaged both by Apple and by Amazon and worked perfectly right out of the box.

Some consider Apple gear is overpriced. With respect to this particular notebook, I certainly do not consider this item overpriced but rather a bargain, considering the quality, speed and ease of use, compared to most light weight laptops with SSD storage. I am still learning the intricacies of the Apple platform but I am very happy with this purchase.

Update 4/27/15: I can't believe I wrote the review above without mentioning the amazing trackpad, which is a delight to use. This trackpad allows you to 'click' by 'pushing' down anywhere on it's surface and that is a big improvement over a physical push click at the bottom left on the older trackpads or the tap to click which always got me in trouble when an attempt to move the cursor was misinterpreted as a click. This ability to physically click anywhere on the trackpad surface sounds simple but makes a huge difference in ease of use.

Update 4/30/15: There seems to be a major problem, at least for some users of this MacBook Pro, when an external monitor is connected and the MacBook is used with the lid closed. After writing my previous review, I connected the MacBook Pro to an external monitor and experienced regular kernel panics that caused the system to reboot unexpectedly. It seemed to only occur when I tried to wake the MacBook from sleep. If the MacBook is used not connected to an external monitor, there has never been a problem with kernel panics. Upon researching this subject I have found a number of forum discussion of this problem of kernel panics, which always seem to occur when an external monitor is connected. Although no one really understands exactly what is going on, it may be a problem with the latest operating system update. I also cannot say how common this problem is, but I definitely am one who experienced it. Right now I have given up on connecting to an external monitor.

This is really a strange time to be shopping for a Mac laptop.  There appears to be so much choice, but when push comes to shove, there's actually very little choice.  You're going to have to be a patient reader to see the big picture here -- so I apologize now for the length of this.

THE BEST OF TIMES

When I say it's the best of times to shop for a Mac, I'm talking about the operating system.  Yosemite.  It's not perfect, but it's pretty much the best OS X since it's introduction.  Once you set up Yosemite your way, it will become your best friend and typically leave you alone.

Unlike Windows 8.1, you won't fear updating your system.  Updates aren't constant.  And you won't need to run an antivirus program or malware program.  You won't need to restore your computer to a prior state.  You won't have to deal with a touch interface that doesn't belong on your laptop.  You won't have to look forward to the 'next' operating system's bells and whistles and promises that should have been given to you a decade ago.

In a nutshell:  your computer isn't a teetering Jenga Tower.  It's not a PC.  It's a Mac.

THE WORST OF TIMES

So Apple has this killer operating system and eco-system.  And Windows doesn't.  So you'd think Apple would JUMP at this moment to grab a better share of the home user market by lowering prices a little.

Please note I said 'a little' before comments come flying in below.  For you see the apologist justification for Apple's high prices is that "once you start trying to match PC prices, it becomes an unprofitable RACE TO THE BOTTOM".  But I didn't say 'match' now did I?  I said I'm surprised Apple hasn't dropped prices A LITTLE.

If you look at the three main choices for 13 inch-ish Macs, you realize you have a choice of either the new anorexic $1299 MacBook 12 incher, a $1299ish MacBook Air, or a $1299ish MacBook Pro.  Not much of a choice if you'd prefer to spend $999.  Right?

What Apple is doing at the moment is taking features away from one laptop to add them to the other... but never do you get all the features you might want.  Or to get those features they add a pricey feature you don't want... and still... you're paying $1299ish somehow.

I'm a lifelong Mac user.  Since 1986.  I've never owned a PC.  (Well, I did briefly recently.  If you spy my reviews you'll see what I've already said:  Windows is terrible.)  Anyway, I worked in Apple Store for years and was respected for shooting straight.  Telling it like it is.  So here we go.

In this day and age of computing on a 13 inch device, here's what most users should get in modern spec --

1.  A Full HD screen (1080p)
2.  8 Gigs of RAM
3.  256 SSD onboard
4.  A processor which can handle your needs

THE SCREEN -- Why would you want a full HD screen?  That sounds like a judgment I've passed but actually isn't.  Apple asks you to accept either lower res (720p I think) or higher (Retina).  And so 1080 is already in the middle there somewhere -- and more than sharp enough for most users.  But if Apple offered you that,in some cases they'd have to drop prices.  And they don't want to do that.

THE RAM -- I have a famed review of the prior MacBook Air on this site.  Where I say 4GBs is not enough RAM.  Oh did the apologists attack me for saying as much.  But the discussion is now moot.  Why?  The new MacBook 12 inch includes 8 gigs of RAM.  Why oh WHY would Apple do that if it wasn't necessary?  Apologists will tell you that the system runs 'fine' on so little RAM because of Yosemite memory pressure and compression tricks.  If that's true, then why did Apple include 8 GBs of RAM on the new unit?  Both can't be true.

256 SSD:  This is the modern solid state storage on phones and pads.  You want this in a laptop because it means you can drop your laptop without fearing the old school spinning disc will die upon impact.  And SSDs make systems FEEL much faster, since access of the information on them moves much quicker.  If SSDs were dirt cheap, you'd want a a terabyte of such storage on board.  Since they're still a little pricey, 256 is better than 128 but nowhere near as expensive as 512.  It's a decent compromise for most users, which can be augmented by either an external hard drive, iCloud solutions, or both for data hogs.

PROCESSOR:  your choice is between Intel power house CPUs and the new Intel Core M.  Both are fine but you have to decide if you're going to be a 'light' computer user or a serious one.  More on this in a bit.

If you look at Apple's current lineup of 13inch-ish laptops, you can't get all of those specs on one unit.  Without a special order that takes you off of Amazon and to Apple's site.  (Ahem.)

MacBook Air --  you can get the fast enough processor and 256 SSD storage, but you win a low res screen (not even 1080p) and you can't get 8 GBs of RAM.  On Apple's site you can add the ram but not the screen -- and your price becomes... $1299.

MacBook Pro -- to get the spec I recommend above, you must spend $1499.  And you're given a Retina display you probably don't need.  Again, a 1080p would do fine here and drop the price.  Why isn't that available?

New 12 inch MacBook -- includes all the spec I recommend except the 1080p screen... but limits you to a 12 inch screen size and the Intel Core M.  For $1299.  This unit is the most absurd to include a Retina screen because it's frankly too small a screen to make Retina matter.

Do you see what's wrong here?

The CEO of Nike once asked Steve Jobs what he thought of Nike's products.  No filter Steve said, "Nike makes some of the best products in the world.  Products that you lust after.  But you also make a lot of crap.  Just get rid of the crappy stuff and focus on the good stuff.

That is EXACTLY what's wrong here.  If you do enough research between the MacBook Air and MacBook Pro lines, you learn the Pro isn't really that much thicker or heavier.  And yet the spec is much better for almost the same price.  And so... we don't really need the 'crappy' MacBook Air line at all, do we?

That new skinny anorexic MacBook should have been launched as a 13 inch 'Air'.  With a 1080p screen standard.  With the spec it currently enjoys:  8 GBs of RAM, 256 SSD, Intel Core M.  Take it or leave for it for $999.  The reason I can price it that way is because Asus sells an extremely similar unit for $699.  Since it lacks Yosemite it's technically not similar at all, but you know what I mean.

Such a MacBook would sell more hotcakes than Dennys.  It wouldn't be a workhorse, but then that's what the MacBook Pro line would be.  An entry level pro with a 1080 P ($999) and then the rest whatever Apple is currently charging for Retina.

Most PC users will tell you that a 1080p laptop for a grand is highway robbery.  I'm willing to say not so fast.  But at $1299?  Yup.  Robbery.

** Sidebar:  this price fixing thing shows itself in the 15 inch MacBook Pro line.  Do you realize you can't get a 15 inch MacBook without coughing up $1999?!?  They force you to have 16GBs of RAM and Retina or it's a no go.  But hey, wait a second... how about a 1080p version of it with 8 GBs of RAM?  Which might be $1499?  Which is still pricey in PC circles but at least reasonable?  You can buy a 15 inch 1080p Chromebook for $349.  I know, I'm comparing Apples with Chromebooks (lol) but I think you see what I see here. **

I'm not trying to convince anyone not to buy a Mac.  I'm trying to show you the shell game currently afoot.  I bet a year from now things will be better balanced.  But it is a worst of times scenario for anyone who feels $1299 is too pricy.

Edit 1 (2015-04-20): Now that I've had this a few days, I've grown more accustomed to the trackpad.  It's an interesting thing, with the force feedback-like operation, but it does feel different to me.  Perhaps that's all in my head knowing that it's fundamentally different.

This is my first Retina display Mac.  I had some learning to do.  Although it's a smaller screen, I found the default setting makes everything appear too large.  That is, I could fit less content on the screen.  Excluding the very sharp lines and edges, why have such a high-resolution display if you can't use it?  If you go to System Preferences and then Display, then select the Scaled option under resolution, you can change from Default to the More Space options to the right.  It really allows me to use the high-resolution screen as I wish.  The middle display option is a nice balance for me in terms of utility and my old eyes.

I've bought my 2015 Macbook pro directly from an Apple Store.  This computer is absolutely wonderful for general everyday use and no doubt has much to offer to a professional.  However, I personally bought this computer as an every day work/play laptop.  I do not like the fact that the new Macs do not have CD drives, don't have LAN ports, and generally you'll have to buy separate "add on" attachments for anything external.  Yes the new Mac is lighter than most laptops but the hassle of carrying around an additional CD drive, maybe an extra hard drive, HDMI conversion cable, and so on and so forth is a big pain.  Yes this is a beautiful machine, but for the every day user this is pretty much a glorified Net Book with a bigger hard drive.

I absolutely love my MacBook Pro 13.3" laptop. I am coming from windows (I have an ASUS gaming PC that I've upgraded,i7 clocked at 3.9 ghz with 16 gb RAM and a ton more). I was extremely hesitant at first from switching from windows to iOS, but i'm glad I did. The MacBook Pro is extremely fast. The bootup time is insane. It is SSD, so everything is extremely quiet compared to my ASUS. Below I will outline just a few of the Pros and Cons of the macbook Pro.

Pros:
- iOS is extremely user friendly and the new iOS X makes life easy as it will convert your windows files to a readable format to iOS.
- The Laptop is made of sturdy materials that I believe will last.
- All SSD, which equals way faster read/write times
- The display is amazing, the best i've ever seen
- the new trackpad is by far my favorite. i prefer it over my mouse.
- The keyboard is sweet. I can't explain what makes it stand out so much, but go to your local BestBuy and play on one and you'll see what i'm saying.
- The overall quality and my personal satisfaction with my purchase has increased my productivity while taking online classes.

Cons
- Price, which I will tell you below how to save money upon purchasing
- The 13.3" is tiny, BUT I connect it to an external monitor.
- Apple offers horrible ROM. Way i got around this is purchasing a 1TB external hard drive and reformatting it to iOS.
- The awesome quality makes you nervous about dropping it. If you do not have a protective case (I suggest getting the new Thule case), your MacBook Pro has a high chance of being destroyed upon impact.
- You do not have as much customization with iOS as with windows, but it's also a lot more stable.

Overall Impression:
I am overall pleased with my MacBook Pro. My wife purchased a MacBook in 2006, and it still operates fine to this day, which says a lot. The most impressive functionality for me with MacBook Pro and iOS is the ability to text, call, and facetime from the laptop itself. Now I'm an active duty Marine and travel places where I do not always have cell phone service, AKA Deployments. The ability to stay in touch with my friends and family via iMessage was a key selling point to me.

Now, for the important part: How to save money when purchasing this laptop. If you are a student or a government worker, Apple offers a discount. Seeing as I am both, I was able to save an incredible amount of money on my MacBook Pro. Best Buy will price match Apple's online offer (which I'm sure amazon will to, but this is how i did it). So Best Buy price matched it to $1,199. Then I received $50 off for being a student and registering my student email on Best Buy.com. So i ended up paying $1,150 for a new MacBook Pro. That's almost $150 off. Being active duty military and not making an incredible amount of revenue, this was a Godsend to me. I hope you guys decide to purchase a new MacBook Pro. I ensure you you will love it. even the people coming from Windows will appreciate it, as I did. Thank you  and have a great day!

I have been a long-term PC user as they are cheaper and my family has never had much money. As I'm now (technically) an adult with a professional career I have more money than I did growing up and am learning quickly that you get what you pay for (as I sit uncomfortably on a couch I got from a discount furniture store).

I bought a laptop several years ago and it cost me a good chunk of change....around $1100. That thing, though, lasted me about 7 years so really not a bad run. When it started going on the fritz while I was finishing grad school I decided to go get a cheap laptop from a big box store so I didn't have to worry about my computer crashing my last semester. The computer itself is okay. Nothing to write home about. But it had Windows 8.1. Whoever developed Windows 8.1 should lose their job as far as I'm concerned. Even with Classic Shell it still was...confusing.

So at this point I've graduated, making better money, and have had awesome experiences with the reliability of Apple products in the past (my iPhone 3G is still around somewhere working....). I did some research online about the Apple laptops and realized the MacBook Pro's were more powerful but the Air's were (obviously) pretty awesome in their own rights based on size, weight, and portability. So I went to the Apple store and played around on the laptops. The 15 inch laptops were sooooo much more and I really didn't need that much screen space. The 11 inch Air's were a bit TOO small so I focused on the 13 inch laptops. I really liked the more powerful Pro and the 13 inch one really wasn't anything horribly bulky or heavy so that's what I brought home.

It's a little bit of a learning curve but I am learning to LOVE the trackpad and it's many gestures. It is absolutely perfect for daily use. It's so much quicker to boot up, load programs, and browse the internet than ANY computer I've had in the past. Since I have the iPhone it is also easy to connect the two devices and share everything between the two.

Is the MacBook Pro completely customizable? Not really. Does it take a bit of getting used to when coming from a PC? Yes. Is it for everybody? No.

Is it great for me and where I'm at right now? Yes. Do you get what you pay for in terms of quality? YES. Does it compare to the $350 laptop I have sitting in my living floor right now, sad and alone? NO.

I had to have a wireless mouse to use with my PC because the trackpad was horrible. I'd randomly click stuff, zoom, etc. but I think I'm actually going to prefer the MacBook without a mouse.
Fantastic computer. I have been using it for a couple of weeks now and the battery life and performance are nothing short of perfect.
Great product

This laptop is built using the best available parts, compared to some of the other laptops available from other manufacturers, it makes the competition very hard for them, many people are under the impression that Apple's computer is overpriced, but the quality of used components justify the price IMO, in fact, there are more expensive laptops with less quality out there.

- Screen: IPS, best technology available for laptops, with a huge contrast ratio of 1000 according to some internet reviews (which can be reduced via software if it too high for you), very rare to find in a laptop, and monitor is also bright enough for outdoor usage, under direct sunlight may be slightly harder to view.

- Design: Thin and light, when compared to other laptops in the same category, and considering it have a huge battery inside.

- Battery: 74.9 Wh, that is quite large, with the current processor, it should allow for a very long time of battery life.
The processor and the screen brightness are the most power hungry components in the laptop. Minimizing the brightness and limiting the number of CPU hungry applications should give you a long battery life, can even go higher than 10 hours of uptime.

- Touchpad: it is still very good when compared to previous model, what seems interesting in this new model is the ability to adjust the how much pressure required to register a click.

- Wifi: 3 streams wireless AC is supported, the widely available for most other laptops out there is usually only a 2 stream wireless AC or wireless N, 3 streams with 3 antennas is extremely rare.

- Processor: The newest released by Intel on first quarter 2015, with increase in performance and more power saving, this is however NOT a quad core processor, if you need a quad core, it is recommended that you wait for next summer for the new 15 inch model.

- Other: RAM: 1866 , SSD up to 1200 MB/s , Graphics processor Intel Broadwell Iris.
Only heavy workstation laptops combine that kind of specs.

What I do not like:

- You have to pay an extra $200 for the SSD upgrade from 128GB to 256GB on the base model, which is unjustifiable to pay that much for only this one difference, but the extra space is needed for comfort of installing different applications or using bootcamp.

- As the previous model, inability to upgrade storage or RAM, so you need to think wisely if you need more RAM or larger SSD before purchasing.

- Only 2 USB 3.0 ports, if you have 1 external USB mouse and 1 external USB harddrive, you are left with no extra ports.
Not the worst issue, but would have been more comfortable to have at least an extra port.
You can still get USB Hub or thunderbolt to USB adapters.

Finally,

This product is the best quality of components without compromising on one component, highly recommended.

If you are not a fan of Apple products, checkout the Dell XPS laptops, another great laptop, with slightly lower specs all around, but with ability to upgrade the SSD, and the base model may cost a bit less that the Mac.
